title: a lifeline parcel unless you live in minard
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsA woman from Minard has been left disappointed after a supermarket failed to deliver on its promise to deliver a special lockdown food package.On its website, Aldi says of its food parcel: #We’ll deliver it straight to your door with full contactless delivery for self-isolators.#As an asthma sufferer self-isolating, Minard resident Tracey Ferguson thought this was a great idea to take the pressure off she and her partner, a key worker in forestry doing -hour shts.Tracey placed the online order on Friday April  for the £. box, containing essentials including handwash, toilet paper, chocolate, UHT milk, part-baked rolls, canned goods, rice, pasta, sauces, tea coffee and biscuits.It was supposed to be delivered by April , but didn#t turn up so Tracey checked the courier website, which advised it was unable to deliver the package, adding #You must take action#.Tracey repeatedly tried to contact Aldi customer services by phone and email.#After several attempts they picked up the phone once, but put me on hold then disappeared,# said Tracey.She was eventually told her money would not be refunded until the package was ed by the courier.Tracey told them the courier hadn#t tried to deliver in the first place.Shortly after the Argyllshire Advertiser contacted Aldi for comment, on May  and after weeks of frustration Tracey received a full refund, a £ online voucher as a #goodwill gesture# and an apology.Later, in an official response, an Aldi spokesperson said: #We apologise that the service Ms Ferguson received fell short of our usual high standards.#We have spoken to her to organise a full refund and will raise this with our delivery partner.#Tracey concluded: #I know it#s not a good time and everyone#s under pressure, but I worked in customer services for  years and you just don#t treat customers like this. Maybe that#s why it#s annoying me so much.#The money#s important, but it#s more about the principle.#

title: council considers question of home working
story: Susan WindramUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsGarden pods could be useful work stations for Argyll and Bute Council staff who are working from home, a senior councillor has claimed.Rory Colville, the authority’s policy lead for support services, suggested the council look at the potential of staff being able to work from home permanently in future – and wondered whether garden pods might help.He put the idea to the council’s business continuity committee after hearing a report on the radio on the facilities’ popularity.It was announced during the week of the meeting that social networking site Twitter was allowing its staff to work from home “forever”they so wished.Many council staff are working from home during the COVIDd- pandemic, and the council committee members themselves were conducting the meeting, yesterday, Thursday May , via Skype.Councillor Colville said: #I was listening to the radio this morning and there was one company which is blossoming in this situation, in that they provide pods to put in your garden to work from home.#They have seen an increase, and some companies, Twitter being one of them, have already decided to move to a permanent arrangement.“As we make decisions in future, I would flag that up. It is not possible for everybody to work from home, as we hear stories of people working off ironing boards et cetera.#Should we move to a permanent position, could we give some consideration to this #Councillor Kieron Green questioned the practicality of the idea, and also sought clarity on when waste and recycling sites are likely to reopen.He said: #It is a great ideayou have a garden, but there will be a lot of us with no gardens in smaller properties.#So will people in these propertiesfrom lockdown earlier than others  What would be the situationthey need to shield  And there are areas with poor broadband as well.#On recycling and refuse collections, there is a comment in the paper about them being resumed, and waste recycling centres being resumed, when safe and sensible to do so.“I agree with that, but it is vague on whether there is a timescale. I am running out of space in my kitchen to store recycling.#In response to the query on waste and recycling centres, council leader Aileen Morton said: #Based on papers that are going to COSLA, I expect Nicola Sturgeon to make an announcement on the position regarding waste and recycling centres.#We will then be able to update our local arrangements.#

title: schools could reopen by august
story: Susan WindramUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsArgyll and Bute Council is working on the assumption that schools willin some form in August, a meeting has heard.Douglas Hendry, executive director with responsibility for education, delivered an update on the authority’s response to the COVID- outbreak at a virtual meeting of its business continuity committee yesterday, Thursday May .A report for the meeting gave details of educational measures, including school meal provision and digital learning, since schools were closed on Friday March .And Mr Hendry said while speaking to the report that August, when schools usually go back after summer, is earmarked for some form ofto lessons, pending lockdown measures.He said: #There is still no clear position, but the assumption we are working on is some form of reopening of schools, although not back to what it was before, in August. Work is going on to prepare for that.#Councillor Lorna Douglas then said: #People have complained about certain things, but I’ve had a lot of good feedback from people about how the council has put things in place.#Mr Hendry mentioned that we hoped that schools would reopen by August. I know that is what has been discussed nationally.#I just wondered whether we could have reports about education and planning, and what is actually happening on how this is moving forward, at our next meeting #Mr Hendry responded: #In terms of education as a whole, there is a high level of framework and we have paid particular attention to matters that have been pressure points.#We will see early learning and childcare, including our , hours programme, and additional support needs, being looked at.#It is pretty clear that there will not be ato pre-lockdown scenarios, so we are looking at things in relation to accommodation and on what basis schools would reopen.#From discussion with a member of staff in education, the phrase that they used was that they would be looking at a blended approach.#We are working on all those things and will have a range of papers coming forward to keep members up to speed.#Councillor Yvonne McNeilly, the council’s policy lead for education, then added: “I am more than happy that we are working transparently and will give updates on these matters.#On a point of clarity, I am absolutely with the first minister on that we approach everything with caution, and a multi-layered approach may not be taken for August because everything is far from clear.#I am in another education group and we have heard about young children who have been in contact with the virus and had a delayed reaction.#They are taking up to a month before starting to manest any real symptoms, so there is a real side issue. It is about doing things extremely cautiously.#The Educational Institute for Scotland, the country’s largest teachers’ union, has previously said that schools should notbefore August.The Scottish Government has not yet stated a timetable for pupils going back to school, but has said abefore the scheduled summer break was unlikely and a phasedwould almost certainly be required.

title: gamers-enjoy-e-sports-success-gala-fairydean-rovers
story: A TEAM of online gamers are representing Gala Fairydean Rovers FC in a virtual football competition.Gas engineer Darren Smith, of Galashiels, helped launch an -a-side league on FIFA  in which his hometown club has been enjoying considerable success.Smith, , told the Border : ldquoConsidering itrsquos the first season, itrsquos been excellent ndash and so has the reaction wersquove got from people.The Scottish league, played on a PlayStation , contains a number of teams representing official clubs, including Berwick Rangers, Greenock Morton andEast Stirlingshire.But the Galashiels side has been performing admirably, according to Smith ndash who has his sights set on a lofty finish.ldquoWersquove only beaten twice, said Smith, whose side currently sit third. ldquoLast Sunday we got beaten and we got beaten on the first day of the season.He added: ldquoWersquore still to play the second-placed team and wersquore still to play the team at the top.ldquoI thinkwe go unbeaten and they drop a few points, itrsquos there to be done and Irsquod be happy with second place.A total of  players have signed up to Galarsquos virtual squad, with three players from the town itself.As the recruitment drive was mainly carried out through Twitter, Smith was able to procure the services of gamers from across Britain and further afield. One of the goalkeepers, for instance, lives in Egypt.Asked to describe what it is like playing a video game in co-operation with  other people, Smith indicated it has been a hugely enjoyable experience.He said: ldquoPlaying with  others is sometimes challenging when it comes to getting everyone on for a certain time.ldquoHowever, being manager of the team, I have the luxury of picking who is in the team and I have managed to get some really good guys in who are competitive but also able to enjoy playing the game, which is what its all about in the end.When the real-le football season is in full swing, Smith takes to the park for Lauder Amateur FC.But, for now, the left-back is quite happy plying his trade for Gala online - and he is already considering adding a second tier to the virtual set-up next season.ldquoThe competition gives people a place to go and relax and enjoy themselves without the stresses of les problems, he said.

title: caring-woman-guarding-door-borders-chemist
story: WHEN the Peebles Fat Face store closed its doors along with every other shop on the High Street, assistant manager Jane McGarry wasnrsquot home for long before going back to work.No sooner had she hung up the closed sign, Jane began a new voluntary post at a vital store directly opposite.She explained: ldquoWe closed on the Saturday before lockdown. I saw a post for help in Boots chemist on the COVID support page on the Monday morning and was in Boots an hour later.Janersquos new role involves manning the door of the chemist as people queue to pick up medicines.ldquoI roughly do five or six hours a day, Monday to Saturday," she said."My main role is basically to make sure I only let two people in the shop at a time.ldquoThe public are great and understanding. I also take repeat prescriptions so people donrsquot have to queue.Jane joked that she probably now knows the layout in Boots better than she does in Fat Face.ldquoIrsquom getting to know where things are in the shop so I can assist people," she said, adding: ldquoIt feels great to do my bit, evenit is just a cheery face or a friendly hello."While Jane helps people by handing in prescriptions, Peebles student Annie Patterson has proved a dab hand at delivering them.Annie is studying veterinary nursing at Edinburgh Napier University and was due to start her summer placement before the coronavirus outbreak.She said: ldquoAt the beginning of the pandemic, I saw that the NHS was recruiting volunteers throughout the UK."I asked Danielle at Bootsthey needed a hand delivering prescriptions. I wanted to use this time I now had available to help others.ldquoI have been doing this Monday to Saturday for six weeks now and itrsquos great because the majority of people are so grateful."

title: ve-day-75th-anniversary-2-coin-much-may-worth---get-one
story: To mark the th anniversary of VE Day -the Royal Mint has released a commemorative pound coin.Hereseverything you need to know about the new collection from the Royal Mint - including how to get your hands on a coin and how much it costs.Why has the Royal Mint made a commemorative coin The Royal Mint website says: ldquoSeventy-fiveyears on [from VE Day], we thank the generation who gave so much and honour their spirit and sacrice.VE Day stands for Victory in Europe Day, and it refers to May , , when Germany surrendered their armed forces during World War II.The coin from the Royal Mint aims to ldquoremember the first hopeful steps towards lasting peace and the promise of a brighter future.The isional director of commemorative coins at the Royal Mint, Clare Maclennan, said that she hoped the VE Day coins would bring Britain together during the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.Maclennan said: ldquoOur VE Day commemorative coin was inspired by a shared sense of community and loyalty.ldquoDuring these challenging times that the nation finds itself in, we may be unable to join with our loved ones to mark this national milestone, but it feels especially important that we come together to protect the older generation that sacriced so much for us.What coins are available to buy If you want to get your hands on the commemorative pound coin from the Royal Mint, you have a few options.The th anniversary of VE Day pound uncirculated coin comes in educational packaging all about VE Day and Winston Churchill. This costs pound.There is also the th anniversary of VE Day silver proof pound coin. This coin is limited edition, with only , made. It costs pound..Next is the th anniversary of VE Day piedfort silver pound coin. Also limited edition, only , have been made. This coin costs pound.Last is the th anniversary of VE Day gold proof pound coin. This is also an extremely limited edition coin, as only  were made. This coin costs pound,.Alternatively, you can purchase a th anniversary of VE Day gold proof pound coin with a period newspaper, which allows you to read the news of VE Day as it was reported from an original period newspaper.This is an extremely limited edition package with only  available to buy. It costs pound, and because itrsquos so rare, yoursquoll need to phone The Royal Mint on    to place an order.For each coin purchased, a donation will be made to the Imperial War Museums.What do the coins look like The coins feature a design which shows the celebrating public with the word lsquovictoryrsquo across the top.Designer Dominique Evans said: ldquoIconic images of VE Day serve to remind us of the magnitude of events.ldquoMillions came together in the streets to celebrate the end of the war in Europe, inspiring me to put the people at the very heart of this coin. The rays evoke search lights, a familiar sight in the skies during wartime, except here they represent rays of home.

title: historic-borders-house-needs-20k-planned-re-opening
story: A STATELY home in the Borders needs pound, so it can re-open to the public in the summer, according to trustees.Paxton House, in Berwickshire, has been closed since the beginning of the coronavirus lockdown in March.But now the Paxton Trust is urging the public to donate by June  so the th century estate can open its doors again in July.Trust chairman Ian Marrian said: ldquoWe want to re-open as soon as itrsquos safe for all and wersquoll have to invest to ensure that safety."We cannot compromise on the conservation of our nationally signicant collections and the glorious natural landscape."But every day without income makes survival a greater challenge."Mr Marrian said the trust is also working "extremely hard" to try to gain a grant to cover the essential running costs for .He added: "We hope that,and when we re-open, we can with your help and attendance make these strange times a little happier.The trust, which has earmarked July  for re-opening, says it needs pound, by the start of the summer to maintain the property, as well as the childrenrsquos playground and gardens.The house was gted to the nation in  by John David Home Robertson, the last laird, for the populations "benefit and enjoyment".Its collection of paintings includes work by Allan Ramsay, Sir Henry Raeburn and Alexander Nasmyth.The house also boasts Scotlands largest collection of Thomas Chippendale furniture.

title: selkirk-firms-help-make-25-000-face-shields
story: TWO Selkirk companies have combined to help make more than , face shields for hospitals and local businesses.Cademuir Engineering and Eadie Bros and Co have worked together since the start of April to supply D-printed visors, of which , have been sent to Selkirk-based workwear distributor Guthrie Group.The Guthrie Groups Selkirk manager Alan Skeldon said: ldquoIts great to have local businesses with the ability to make face shields, allowing us to supply to local healthcare facilities.A club of engineering enthusiasts based in Edinburgh, called Edinburgh Shield Force, contacted Eadie Bros for help making personal protective equipmentfor frontline workers.The engineers needed headbands for the face shields they were distributing to Scottish healthcare workers, including those at the Borders General Hospital.Using Eadie Brosrsquo injection-moulding tool, Cademuir made the headbands using state-of-the art equipment which enables each part to be robotically handled, minimising contamination risk and increasing the production rate to , a day.Cademuir Engineering production manager Marc Phaup said: ldquoIts fantastic to be involved in this important project for our NHS, along with supplying local businesses like Guthrie Group.ldquoThere are a lot of dferent groups who have come together to achieve the goal of getting PPE to our frontline workers.A spokesperson for the Edinburgh Shield Force added: ldquoThis project has only been possible because of the combined experience of our team, the tireless dedication of our volunteers and the flexibility and hard work of our partners Eadie Bros and Co and Cademuir Engineering.Edinburgh Shield Force is relying on a fundraising appeal, which you can access through this link.

title: 100th-staging-agricultural-show-postponed
story: FARMERS will have to wait until next year for the th staging of a Borders agricultural show.Organisers of Yarrow  Ettrick Pastoral Society Show have taken the decision to cancel the  edition.The societys secretary Alison Renwick said the committee "felt duty-bound" to call off the showpiece.She added: ldquoThis yearrsquos show would have been particularly memorable, as committee members had already started working on a number of special projects to commemorate the th staging.ldquoThese plans will, of course, now be carried over to the  event and Irsquom very confident next yearrsquos show will prove every bit as successful as this yearrsquos would have been.Although the first show staged by the Yarrow  Ettrick Pastoral Society took place in September, , the societyrsquos origins stretch back  years prior to that with the formation of the Selkirk Farmer Club .The new societyrsquos formation came after a public meeting was held in the Gordon Arms in May, , to "consider the desirability of forming a society for the purpose of organising an annual show of sheep and cattle".Descendants of farmers present at that inaugural meeting continue to live and work in the Yarrow and Ettrick Valleys, thereby helping to keep alive the traditions and high standards which have become the hallmark of the societyrsquos past  shows.The organisers added: "We would like to take this opportunity to thank everyone involved with Yarrow Show, including all volunteers, sponsors, traders, exhibitors and public, whose support is essential to the future of the show."The society looks forward to welcoming you back next year."

title: 7-books-house-worth-fortune

title: readers-invited-subscribe-border-telegraph-website
story: NEWSPAPERS across the world are being hit by falling sales and plummeting advertising revenues as the coronavirus outbreak continues.The Border is among the titles which have been lucky enough to continue printing ndash but now we are seeking your help.To make sure we can afford to keep providing trusted and quality local news, we are inviting readers to subscribe to our website.For justpound per week, you will be able to access unlimited articles, with far fewer adverts than you see at the moment.Up until now, our website has been completely free to use, but the pandemic has meant we can no longer keep it that way.Meanwhile,you would prefer to receive a physical edition of the paper, home delivery has never been easier to arrange.To get free delivery for six weeks, you can call    and our team will take your details over the phone.You might even have a friend or relative who would appreciate the service, too ndash why not arrange home delivery for them as well Any support you can give to your local newspaper is keenly appreciated by our small team of staff.You can sign up to the website byclicking hereor phone    for home delivery.

title: borders-college-students-deliver-medicine-vulnerable-folk
story: BORDERS College students are delivering medicine to vulnerable peoplersquos homes during lockdown.A total of  students and staff have given up their time to drop off more than  prescriptions across the region.The colleges work placement co-ordinator Verity Hislop said: "The students are quite happy to do it ndash they enjoy it."The college is working with NHS Borders and Scottish Borders Council to run the scheme, which is being led by Ms Hislop.She said: ldquoAlthough wersquove no direct contact with the iniduals wersquore delivering to, we get a wave or a smile or a thank you from a distance."And we certainly know they are appreciative, from the expression on their face."If we didnrsquot deliver, they wouldnrsquot be able to get their medicines.ldquoThese are iniduals who fall into the vulnerable group ndash theyrsquove been told by the NHS they need to isolate.ldquoThere was a huge demand on pharmacies and a lot of iniduals in ious communities fall into the vulnerable category."We sent out a call to staff and students ndash but only those who are PVGscheme members."All the Borders staff fall under that, and also the health and social care students."Originally, pharmacies notied the NHS Borders Transport Hub about prescriptions that needed to be picked up.But now pharmacies are contacting the Borders College delivery team directly with their requests.ldquoThe Transport Hub emailed me with requests for prescription pick-ups from the pharmacy, said Ms Hislop, ldquoand then I would arrange for volunteers to go to the pharmacies, pick up the prescription and deliver them to the people who needed them.ldquoBut now wersquore getting phone calls directly from the pharmacies, with the increase in demand.She added: ldquoBorders College sees its role as supporting our community and during these unprecedented times there is a desire to contribute and add value by volunteering.ldquoThe college is exceptionally proud and grateful to everyone who is involved. This collaborative mission helps to protect vulnerable groups within the community and potentially saves lives.ldquoA huge thank you to all the volunteers, NHS Borders and NHS Transport Hub.

title: gala-rfc-hails-generosity-fans-1-000-goes-foodbank
story: GALASHIELS rugby players have raised more than pound, for the local foodbank ndash and delivered carloads of supplies.Over two successive weekends, Gala RFC invited supporters to drop off food at the gates of Scott Park.Gala president Ian Dalgleish said: ldquoEveryonersquos generosity was fantastic.The weekend of April - saw nearly pound left by players, committee members, supporters and the general public ndash in addition to bags of groceries.The second weekend of collections, on May , raised pound ndash including a bottle of coins totalling pound from residents at Abbotsford Court.Mr Dalgleish said: ldquo[Captain] Euan Dods and [vice captain] Rex Jeffrey and other volunteers were collecting the food and donations at Scott Park, and then the bags were delivered to St Peterrsquos Church for the foodbank.ldquoThe bottle of coins donated by the folk at Abbotsford Court was pound ndash they donrsquot have a lot of money to give out but when they found out there was pound in the bottle they actually topped it up to pound.Galashiels Foodbank co-ordinator John Tucker said: ldquoWe are really thrilled to have all this local support.ldquoNearly pound, was raised in two weekends, and Herculean amounts of food ndash two carloads of food both weekends ndash so our stocks are right up to where we want them to be, which is wonderful.ldquoIn times of hardship people are thinking of each other. The public have really got their support behind this initiative and they just came along with food and money.ldquoBefore COVID, we were giving out maybe  carrier bags of food a week."At [the viruss peak] about two weeks ago we gave out  ndash a fourfold increase in demand.And the foodbank is not the only local charity to benefit from the generosity of the rugby club players.Gala Menrsquos Shed, whose members are making face visors for care workers, was the grateful recipient of a pound donation by the rugby club.Scottish Borders Menrsquos Shed developer Ross Hall described the donation as "fantastic".He said: "It took us over a wee setback in terms of supply, and Gala stepped in at just the right time to help us make more visors."So we had a wee break due to funding and now wersquore back on track. Fantastic news."

title: aussie-rugby-player-caring-galashiels-lockdown
story: A KIND-HEARTED Australian rugby player has been delivering food to elderly folk in the Borders town he currently calls home.Gala RFC forward Cody Roman, , moved from Wollongong, New South Wales, in October last year.When coronavirus put paid to his plans to explore more of the Borders, he decided to channel his free time into volunteering as a driver with Food Train.He said: ldquoIrsquom fortunate that Irsquom mobile so I want to get out and help those who are less fortunate or in need."For six weeks, Cody has been dropping off food to residents who are self-isolating.He said: ldquoIt got to the end of winter and I was looking forward to seeing some nice summer days, and then this [lockdown] happened.ldquoThe club put a post on social media askingthere were any guys ready to help out with anything, like shopping or dog-walking or anything that people were unable to do now, for people who had to self-isolate.ldquoThe Food Train commented on the post, and I was like, lsquoIrsquoll do itrsquo. And Irsquove being doing it for six weeks now.ldquoItrsquos been really good ndash everyone appreciates it. Some people who live alone might not have seen anyone for a few days, so theyrsquore very happy when we come out to them and have a chat.ldquoSome of them are very excited and grateful. Some of them offer us a cup of tea and we have to let them down easy."Despite being so far from his home Down Under, Cody is coping well with the coronavirus lockdown.ldquoItrsquos not too bad, with Facebook and social media and stuff. I can just send messages and give people a call."And Irsquom pretty fortunate where I live ndash everyonersquos very friendly.

title: ex-lauder-footballer-toasts-50th-anniversary-cup-win
story: A REUNION to mark the th anniversary of Lauder Amateur FC clinching the South of Scotland Cup has been cancelled due to coronavirus.Lauder triumphed - over Tweeddale Rovers at Netherdale, Galashiels, on May , .Members of the successful side had been planning to meet up this summer, but COVID- has put paid to the proposal.George Threadgall, , told the Border that he still treasures memories of Lauderrsquos achievement.ldquoIt was like the European Cup for us, said the former defender, adding: ldquoI think half of Lauder was there that night.Led by coaches Jim Brotherston and Alex McDonald, Lauder went down - through an own goal, recalled Mr Threadgall, before roaring back to put their noses in front.After Rovers hoofed a penalty kick over the bar in the dying minutes, Mr Threadgall and team-mates celebrated a famous victory when they arrived home.ldquoYou go to Lauder and mention the South team and locals will bore you to tears about how big a thing it was for the town, said Mr Threadgall, a retired engineer living in Linlithgow.Lauderrsquos goals came courtesy of forwards Jimmy Gillie and Stan Seaton, said Mr Threadgall, with centre-half Kenny Rutherford being the unfortunate player who turned the ball into his own net.The reunion had been planned for late July or early August in Lauderrsquos Golden Bannock pub, said Mr Threadgall.Guests would have included Dave Elrick, now living in South Africa, who was Lauder Cornet in the year he helped his hometown side to the cup.Mr Threadgall, a grandfather, was himself Lauder Cornet in .

title: uk-government-refuses-share-galashiels-virus-results
story: THE UK Government has refused to sendstatistics to the Border relating to coronavirus tests carried out in Galashiels this month.The army ran a temporary testing facilityfor self-isolating key workers and their relatives at the Netherdale car park in the first week of May.But a UK Government spokesperson told this newspaper that the number of people seen at ldquoinidual test sites would not be disclosed.A follow-up request for further details on the Netherdale centre was also turned down this week.Details included whether an extension had been granted.The pop-up facility was one of dozens set up earlier this month as part of the UK Governments push for more testing. The Borders centre was scheduled to run between May  and May .Self-isolating key workers with symptoms were eligible for tests, as were their relatives living under the same roof.These are the questions which the Border posed to the UK Government on May :How many people have visited the Galashiels testing centre so far How many of those have received a positive diagnosis for the virus How do the number of visitors to the site in Galashiels compare to those in other mobile centres established in Scotland How do the number of positive cases confirmed at the Galashiels site compare to other centres in Scotland What further advice treatment is offered to those who test positive at a drive through centre Will the government extend theof time the town has this mobile testing facility beyond May  As the sites are only open to those showing signs of the virus or who are living with someone with symptoms, what is the purpose of these tests

title: furlough-extended-october-questions-answered
story: Chancellor Rishi Sunak has saidthe UK Governmentrsquos furlough scheme willbe extended until the end of October.But what does it all mean for workers and businesses Heres what you need to know.What will happen to workers on furlough Mr Sunak said they will continue to receive  per centof their pay ndash up to pound, a month ndash until the end of October.This extends the original furlough scheme to eight months since it was launched in March.The Chancellor also said there will be the possibility of part-time s for staff from August, pointing out that manufacturers have been asking for staggered shts to reopen production lines.Are there more details on part-time s and can I take a job where The details will be published later this month, but Mr Sunak stressed to MPs that furloughed workers can take jobs where while on the scheme.Government advice says: ldquoIf your contract allows, you may undertake other employment while your current employer has placed you on furlough, and this will not affect the grant that they can claim under the scheme.However, staff cannot work for their employer while furloughed.Will the Government continue covering the cost The Government will fund the furlough scheme, which has supported seven million jobs at a cost of pound billion a month, until the end of July.After that, companies will be expected to make a contribution to the payments, although the amount workers take home will not fall below the  per cent mark.How much will businesses be expected to pay towards furlough The details will be published later this month, the Chancellor said, but it is likely to be judged on a sector-by-sector basis, similar to the details published on Monday by the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategyfor companies looking to reopen under new ldquoCovid Secure measures.With certain sectors ing to some normality, others, including restaurants and gyms, remain unlikely to reopen fully for several months.Can we expect to see furlough extended beyond October The Government has said it will continue to monitor the situation and is willing to adjust advice accordingly.But Mr Sunak made clear it is unlikely to be extended.He told the Commons: ldquoWe will keep everything under review but my expectation is by thenthe scheme should end. Wersquove stretched and strained to be as generous as possible to businesses and workers, which is why we have made the decision that wersquove made today.The Chancellor added: ldquoBut hellip this scheme is expensive. Itrsquos the right thing to do. The cost of not acting would have been far higher but itrsquos not something that can continue indefinitely into the future. Eight months of total support is a considerable amount of time.Are there any other signicant changes to the furlough scheme More details will come this month, but MPs raised concerns from self-employed workers who pay themselves via idends, asking whether they would be able to receive further support.However, Mr Sunak insisted current support is strong enough.Why is the Government announcing the extension now Under employment laws, companies must start informing any staff they plan to make redundant within  days of any changes.The previous furlough scheme was due to end by July, meaning consultations would need to begin imminently, but the extension to October will address it.

title: borders-actor-jack-lowden-narrates-bbc-football-documentary
story: BORDERS actor Jack Lowden contributed to a BBC documentary aired across Scotland last night .The former Earlston High School pupil narrated Return to Real Kashmir FCabout a Scottish football managers job in Asia.The BBC Scotland show was a sequel to an earlier programme documenting Davie Robertsons first season in charge.Lowden, , narrated the story of Robertsonsto the disputed Himalayan region.In Robertsons playing career, he racked up more than  appearances for both Aberdeen and Rangers, following up with spells at Leeds United and Montrose.

title: let-borders-garden-centres-open-soon-says-msp
story: BORDERS residents should be allowed to visit garden centres soon, according to a politician.Christine Grahame MSP has asked the Scottish Government to consider re-opening such businesses with safety measures in place.Ms Grahame, of the SNP, highlighted the "physical and mental wellbeing benefits" of gardening.The member for Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale addressed Holyroods rural economy and connectivity committee this morning.She said: ldquoAny re-opening of businesses of course needs to be done in a safe manner, giving proper consideration to the safety of both staff and the public."Irsquom optimistic that this may be possible with garden centres soon, given the physical and mental wellbeing benefits gardening can offer for us all in lockdown.ldquoIf yoursquore fortunate enough to have access to a garden it can make a real dference and being able to buy some supplies for it could be a real boost to many. Indeed even a window box can make a dference. While you can currently buy online, it is not as satisfactory.ldquoOur horticultural sector has been hit hard by lockdown, with many businesses losing out on what would be one of their busiest periods of trade in spring and early summer."This not only affects the big well known chains, but smaller local businesses and growers.ldquoI welcome news that this is being given serious consideration and I trust the Scottish Government will authorise re-opening soon."

title: john-lamont-cancels-summer-tour-first-time-14-years
story: A BORDERS politician has announced he is cancelling his summer surgery tour for the first time in more than a decade.John Lamont MP and Rachael Hamilton MSP, both Conservatives, had been due to visit  towns and villages over the summer.But with coronavirus restrictions in place, the pair are scrapping their plans.Mr Lamont, who formerly held Ms Hamiltons Holyrood seat, expressed sadness that he would be missing an annual "highlight" for himself.He said: "Irsquom really disappointed that for the first time in  years, it will not be happening this summer."The member for Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk ndash who won his first parliamentary election in  ndash said it is important to follow government advice aimed at limiting the spread of COVID-.He added that he continues to hold surgeries over the phone.Ms Hamilton, who represents Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire in the Scottish Parliament, said she is also "disappointed" about the tour cancellation.She added: "I am very much looking forward to meeting constituents again in hopefully the near future when the restrictions are safely lted."

title: borders-businessman-making-living-unwanted-trees
story: AN ENTREPRENEUR is enjoying success by helping to make houses, animal shavings and food pallets.Douglas Mathison, , of Peeblesshire, fells trees across the south of Scotland through his company Agrorest.ldquoEven with the poorest quality timber, you can still get a lot of use out of it, says Mr Mathison, explaining that unwanted woods on farms and estates have the potential to serve a iety of purposes.Once the timber has been taken to the sawmill, Mr Mathison says, the best of it gets transformed into timber-framed houses, while the scraps might ultimately line a rabbit hutch.When Agrorest was founded in , it served a role that was ldquounique in the south of Scotland, according to Mr Mathison.Established firms often shunned the type of tasks that Agrorest expressed an interest in, he says.ldquoWhen I first started, we were the only one in the south of Scotland that was doing this work on a very small basis, Mr Mathison says.ldquoWersquove been taking on an increasing workload, focusing on smaller jobs that other companies are not interested in working on.Although there are now three or four other firms carrying out a similar role in the region, according to Mr Mathison, Agrorest continues to field enquiries from Kilmarnock to West Linton and beyond.Explaining the typical process, Mr Mathison says an initial phone call will often lead to a site visit, which in turn results in Mr Mathison estimating the potential financialthat could be made on a patch of woodlandfelled.If the farmer wishes to press ahead and Mr Mathison secures a licence from Scottish Forestry, Agrorest will send in the machinery, remove the trees and take the timber to sawmills.The farmer can be paid within a few weeks, according to Mr Mathison, who shares a portion of the money he receives from the mills.Aside from felling, Agrorest carries out replanting and also manages a number of estates.Mr Mathison says his success has overcome a historical perception among certain landowners that woodland is ldquonot worth bothering about.In his experience, he says, an undermanaged patch of trees will be worthy of attention ldquonine times out of .Mr Mathison is a former Peebles High School pupil who went on to study rural business management in Edinburgh.He launched Agrorest after a stint working for a large timber harvesting company.

title: 22m-coronavirus-support-approved-borders-businesses
story: MORE than pound million in coronavirus support has been approved for Borders businesses.Scottish Borders Councilhas been managing a portion of the Scottish Governmentrsquos Business Support Fund.More than , payments have now been processed, according to the local authority, amounting to a total of pound. million.Two forms of one-off help are available ndash a pound, grant and a pound, grant, with dfering eligibility criteria.Application forms can be accessed here.

title: 2-000-payments-approved-self-employed-people-borders
story: SELF-EMPLOYED people in the Borders have started receiving money from the council in the form of coronavirus support.The Newly Self-Employed Hardship Fund was launched on May .Since then,  people have been approved for a one-off payment of pound,, according to Scottish Borders Council.The money has been made available by the Scottish Government, with people eligible to applythey set up in business on or after April , .

title: golfers-raise-10-000-peebles-golf-club
story: GOLFERS have donated more than pound, to help Peebles Golf Club while the course is closed.The clubs fundraising drive, launched after the coronavirus lockdown, collected more than pound, last month.Les Biscomb, of the clubs sponsorship sub-committee, hailed the generosity of donors.Reflecting on the campaign so far, he said: ldquoItrsquos been a tremendous success."Unlike golf clubs south of the border, Scottish courses remain closed ndash meaning clubhouse coffers continue to struggle.But the idea of setting up a fundraiser in Peebles has already been vindicated, according to Mr Biscomb.He said: "As a team, we came up with the idea of, while wersquore in lockdown, our members might have vastly reduced income ndash theyrsquore being paid to work at home or are pensioners ndash but therersquos nowhere to spend your money at the moment."You canrsquot go to golf, you canrsquot go down the pub, you canrsquot go to restaurants, many people arenrsquot driving anywhere, so we thought, while wersquore in lockdown, why donrsquot we ask the members in Peebles, who are kindhearted and generous, to put something each month towards a crowdfunder.Comments by donors on the website include, Have my coffee money for the coming month otherwise Irsquoll probably fritter it away and Glad to donate again to ensure our club survives.The sub-committee originally set a target of pound, each month, but received more than pound, in April.Mr Biscomb said: ldquoWe would have been delightedwersquod raised the pound, but in the very first month alone we got to pound,."Some of those were one-offs, so people just wanted to join in with the giving and the spirit of helping the club but even so,you look at May, wersquore already at pound,.ldquoWe were hoping for this to continue for two or three months, pound, a month, just to add in the coffers."This isnrsquot funding thatrsquos needed immediately ndash from a cash perspective, Peebles is doing well."This is really for the quiet periods. Once we turn the corner into next year, thatrsquos really when we might need this money, in the quieter days.ldquoBut who knows whatrsquos going to happen with lockdown, and when wersquore going to get cash back through other means, like the bar and catering, and visitors.Currently, all club staff are on furlough, with the exception of head greenkeeper Steve Borthwick.ldquoSteversquos going a fantastic job, said Mr Biscomb. "The course is in magnicent condition ndash it is very tempting to get out there.Meanwhile, British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has announced that golf clubs in England can re-open, as long as social distancing guidelines are followed.Mr Biscomb conceded he is "quite jealous", but indicated he is satisfied with the Scottish rules.He said: ldquoIrsquod love to get out on the golf course. But equally, we understand that the Scottish Government is not ready because the stats are not there."Theyrsquore not comfortable with opening golf clubs and we have to respect that."Hopefully, in a few weeksrsquo time,the number [of virus cases] comes down, we can start to get out in ones and twos."For now, we have to live with it and be sensible."Wersquore in the eighth week already ndash another couple of weeks wonrsquot do any harm."Itrsquos achievable to be sensible for another few weeks.Donations to Peebles Golf Club can be made via: www.justgiving crowdfunding pgcmembersappealfund

title: mountain-bikers-told-ride-within-limits-lockdown
story: MOUNTAIN bikers have been issued with guidance during lockdown.Scottish Cyclinghas outlined a series of dos and donts following the Scottish Governments go-ahead for people to exercise more than once a day.There are four rules cyclists and mountain bikers must adhere to under the new SC guidelines:Only ride from your home ndash it is not essential travel to go mountain biking or cycling and you may face enquiries from the policeyou are stopped en route or ing from a ride. All Forestry and Land Scotland car parks and trails, including the stanes sites, remain closedDo not go far ndash whilst you can go exercise for longer, we recommend riding close to where you live and not into remote areas ndash think more smaller loops rather than one longer remote rideRide well within your limits ndash only ride on trails that are that you are very confident you will be able to ride safely and within your competency. It is highly unlikely that mountain rescue are back to full operations ndash consider the fact that a full rescue may not be possible and may take longer to get to youOnly cycle with members of your own household - keep a safe distance when passing other cyclists or pedestrians.Mountain biking trails such as the stanes at Glentress, Peebles, and Innerleithen are closed until further notice to restrict travel to the trails and for safety as they are not being maintained as they were before lockdown.However, walking trails owned by Forestry and Land Scotland are open to members of the public who can access them without using transport.

title: subway-store-galashiels-busy-since-re-opening

title: borders-lib-dems-select-ettrick-roxburgh-berwickshire-candidate
story: THE Liberal Democrats have selected a candidate for next years Holyrood election.Jenny Marr will stand for the Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire constituency ndash currently held by Conservative Rachael Hamilton.The former Selkirk High pupil said: "Irsquom thrilled to have been chosen to represent Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire for the Scottish Liberal Democrats."We are living in extraordinary times and I have been blown away by how communities across the Borders have rallied to support each other."The most important thing we can do as politicians and political parties is to provide assistance to anyone that needs it, learn from our experiences and work to address inequalities which have manest."The vote is set to take place on Thursday, May  of next year.

title: borders-based-msp-introduces-online-advice-surgeries
story: A BORDERS-BASED MSP is introducing video surgeries for his constituents.Paul Wheelhouse, who represents the South of Scotland, has had to temporarily close his Hawick office due to the coronavirus outbreak.But from next Friday, Borderers will be able to have a face-to-face meeting ndash without leaving their homes.Mr Wheelhouse said: "Video advice surgeries will be secure and confidential. Constituents will be able to talk to me as though we were sitting down together in person."I fully appreciate that many people do not have video-conferencing technology, or do not even have the internet in their home. For those people, my office is still contactable by telephone at this time."The online advice surgeries are to complement, not replace, other forms of communication. I would strongly encourage anyone who needs my support to get in touch, either by email or phone, and myself and my team will assist in any way we can."Mr Wheelhousersquos first online surgery will take place from pm on Friday, May .To make an appointment, email: paul.wheelhouse.msp@parliament.scot

title: 75-students-without-laptop-get-device-borders-college
story: BORDERS College has loaned laptops to  students who did not have regular access to a suitable device at home.With face-to-face classes cancelled due to coronavirus restrictions, learning has been taking place remotely.Student who did not have adequate laptops of their own have been allowed to borrow from the Galashiels campus.Sport and exercise student Harrison Dixon, from Earlston, said he was "delighted" with the scheme.He said: ldquoMy personal computer is old and struggling to work with some of the new applications and online resources that we are now using, so I spoke with my course tutor who made me aware of the loan scheme, and I was delighted when it was delivered last week."Having the laptop will allow me to continue with my studies remotely.The college says it has loaned a total of  laptops, including those allocated through its bursary programme.Head of IT Scott Moncrieff said: ldquoBefore the college closed, we were able to prepare and distribute  laptops to students for use."Since lockdown, we have had an additional  requests, which we have been able to fulfil.ldquoAny students who find themselves in the situation that continuing their education is not possible, because they donrsquot have an appropriate device, should contact their course tutor or achievement coach, and they will make the appropriate arrangements.

title: historic-borders-houses-feature-visitscotland-campaign
story: HISTORIC homes in the Borders are featuring in a social media campaign by VisitScotland.The tourist organisation has launched #AWindowOnScotland, which asks people to take a photo from their window.Traquair House, Peeblesshire, is among the stately homes in the Borders taking part, with views from the th century Aikwood Tower, near Selkirk, also being shared across social media.Gillian Steele, chairwoman of Big Houses in the Scottish Borders, said: "I donrsquot think people will necessarily forget we are here, but with us all looking out of our windows dreaming of that day when we can travel again, and indulge our passion for Scottish heritage, this campaign strikes a chord."VisitScotlandrsquos #AWindowOnScotland campaign provides us with a great visual opportunity to continue to promote our Houses, their gardens and their wildle from the same perspective as everyone at home."Irsquom encouraging all the Big Houses to take part, and I hope between the eleven of us we will give visitors a reminder of how beautul our Houses and gardens look this month."The campaigns hashtag has been used , times, with towns and villages across the Borders taking part.Historic buildings participating include Thirlestane Castle, near Lauder, and Mellerstain House, near Kelso.VisitScotlands regional leadership director Paula Ward said: ldquoWersquore thrilled at the reaction to #AWindowOnScotland from residents across the Scottish Borders and heartened that businesses are engaging with the campaign and using the opportunity to share their windows on Scotland with the world during this challenging time.ldquoThe staycation market will be a key driver in the countryrsquos economic recovery and the many wonderful views people have been sharing while they stay at home will title: national-express-plans-resume-coach-services-july-1
story: National Express has started selling UK coach tickets as it plans to restart services on July .The tickets will be available for a "core coach network" andwill focus on large and medium-sized towns and cities.Revenue dropped about  per cent in April compared withthe same month last year, National Express revealed, as the Government advised Britons to keep away from public transport.Nevertheless, Ebitdawas positive and slightly ahead of expectations as National Express slashed costs by about pound million.What hasNational Express said In a statement to customers, National Express said: "We have extended the temporary suspension of our coach services."A restricted timetable is currently scheduled to resume from Wednesday, July , ."Please note, however, all services are subject to change depending on Government advice."For thosethat have an upcoming journey booked with us on or before June ,  and would like to amend your booking, you can do so for free, for travel any time in the next  months."There is no need to contact us straight away, just completeour ticket amendment formbefore your original outward journey and get back in touch with us when yoursquore ready to travel again."If you do not wish to amend your ticket to another date, we will provide a full refund. If you havenrsquot already done so, please completeour refund formand we will process your refund within  days."Please stay safe and well and, when the time is right, we look forward to welcoming you back on board."Where does National Express travel to The company runs coach services across the UK, including Manchester to Coventry, London to Worthing, Newcastle via Darlington to London, Liverpool to Leeds, Edinburgh and Glasgow to London, plus Bradford to London.

title: graphic-designer-reveals-inspired-borders-kids
story: A GRAPHIC designer is helping to keep families entertained during lockdown after creating free colouring packs.Kate Pearson, , who owns K Graphic Design, has created six art packs to help ease the boredom of being stuck indoors.Kate, of Peebles, said: "I absolutely love my job because I get to be creative every day."Each pack features dferent activities for children ndash and adults ndash including colouring, design, and games like word searches.Kate said: "Just before lockdown, I spoke to the pupils at my old primary school, Priorsford Primary School, about my career."I left feeling inspired by their enthusiasm and the idea of activity packs was born."She had planned to print the packs but wanted them to be accessible so made them digital ndash a decision which has paid off.The downloads page on her website has been visited more than , times in the last two months, she said.Kate ensured that each pack had something for everyone, with themes including rainbows and dinosaurs."They were designed with young people in mind, but have proved to be just as popular with adults ndash especially the dinosaur one," said Kate.Kate also owns Glass Bulldog Wedding Stationary, and with wedding fairs for  cancelled or postponed, both sides of her business have taken a knock."Ninety per cent of my bookings have been cancelled or postponed until next year ndash many of my suppliers are affected too," said Kate."I really feel for all businesses facing closure and couples postponing their weddings."Like everyone, the biggest challenge of COVID- is not seeing friends and family, but staying at home is such a small price to pay to stay safe ndash especially now lsquoNeighboursrsquo is back on five days a week!"Kate ed to Peebles only a few years ago, after enjoying multiple career roles including as a wedding planner and working for a London-based design agency.Looking to the future, Kate already has three new packs in mind and hopes to eventually print the activity books.She also hopes that once the Borders s to normal, many of her usual services will be back up and running, especially those catered for weddings and events."My clients range from small local start-ups to The Botanic Gardens and Amazon ndash no two days are the same," she said."Going freelance also means I can take my dog, Dr Frankenstein, to work. What more could you ask for "

title: battersea-boss-offers-insight-dogs-cats-coping-lockdown
story: Le under lockdown has yielded an unexpected bonus for some of Battersearsquos loneliest animals ndash unlimited cat cuddles and double daily walkies.The south London-based charity, ordinarily home to up to  cats and dogs across its three sites, currently has around  would-be pets cared for by a skeleton staff as social distancing and temporary safety measures introduced following the coronavirus outbreak continue to pose challenges for operations.But despite the changes ndash and a multimillion-pound drop in its revenue stream ndash Battersea Dogs and Cats Home said its long-term residents have been enjoying the extra attention after staff doubled rehoming efforts and sent another  animals out for fostering in the week leading up to lockdown, leaving the number of furry occupants at just a fraction of their normal capacity.Rob Young, head of centre operations, told the PA news agency: ldquoThe animals are quite happy, the ratio of staff per animal is probably higher than it normally would be before the lockdown so all the dogs are getting at least two walks a day along with some socialisation, and all the cats are getting as many cuddles as they wish.ldquoNot all cats like a cuddle as you probably know.ldquoTherersquos no stress, withtrains going past the Battersea centre in London in particular.ldquoThe dogs havenrsquot been walked off site because we didnrsquot want to risk it in that way. Otherwise wersquove got the paddocks, wersquove got the green areas within the three centresas well, so theyrsquove been getting a lot of attention. Theyrsquove been quite happy.vw,vw,px, px"Bounty, an eight-year-old domestic short-hair, who loves being in the sun Mr Young said the charity was ldquoinundated with requests to temporarily foster animals as lockdown restrictions were introduced, and said they were concerned some pets would no longer be wanted as vast numbers of people were urged to work from home.He said: ldquoWe were worried that wersquod see a lot of animals abandoned at our door because of the situation that people find themselves in, but wersquove not seen that either.ldquoI think wersquove been pleasantly surprised with how the public have reacted quite responsibly and the great British public being the animal lovers that they are, I think theyrsquove responded really well. So wersquore really pleased actually how itrsquos gone so far.The charity has now received clearance from Defra to begin rehoming animals, under strict conditions, while preparing to reopen properly when allowed to do so.vw,vw,px, px"Rob Young praised the public for their responsible attitude to taking on pets during lockdown But despite the workaround, the pandemic has caused its revenue stream to be severely affected through a lack of key fundraising events such as marathons.Mr Young said: ldquoWe expect to lose an awful lot of money over the course of this year. We think anything up to about pound million over the next  months.ldquoSo wersquore able to carry on ing as we always would. We have enough reserves to be able to care for our animals and look after our staff.vw,vw,px, px"Judy the six-year-old Belgian shepherd dog is among those waiting for adoption ldquoBut obviously it is a concern that we arenrsquot able to fundraise like we used to do, the same as everybody .For more information on adoption, visit battersea.org.uk.push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Battersea boss offers insight into how its dogs and cats are coping in lockdown

story: The image was posted on social media by close family friend Davie Martin, on behalf of the family, who described the image as ldquopeaceful.The caption alongside the image read: ldquoYes its our wee warrior Mekala outside in the hospital grounds for the first time in god knows how long.ldquoSo emotional looking at this just trying to imagine what Mekala is just sitting there thinking about. title: seal-pup-spotters-asked-share-photos
story: Zoologist Donald Malone, a former pupil of Stenton Primary and Dunbar Grammar Schools, will send them to friends at the Sea Mammal Research Unitat the University of St Andrews, who keep databases of seal images and attempt to identy iniduals from them.Mr Malone said: ldquoThis would help gain an idea of the number of both harbour and grey seals around the coast of East Lothian.He added: ldquoThey can also keep a lookout for pups, as harbour seals give birth in June and July and grey seals from September to December. Females need to give birth on land though.ldquoGrey seal pups are born with the white lunugo fur and have to stay on land much more until they moult this off around three weeks after giving birth.He saidanyone spots a seal entangled in material such as fishing gear, they should contact British Divers Marine Le Rescuebdmlr.org.uk index.php, which has trained people in East Lothian who will try to capture and free the seal.Mr Malone, who studied zoology at University of Glasgow, has been through this training and has had to aid hundreds of seals all over the world.He was delighted to capture on camera a large group of around  seals, some pregnant, near the Musselburgh lagoons while out for his daily exercise on a cycle from his Edinburgh home.They were hauled out on exposed rocks, just offshore and past the lagoons, heading towards Prestonpans.Mr Malone said: ldquoHarbour seal numbers have actually been in quite drastic decline around Scotland, especially on the east coast, so it was good to see this big group of them.ldquoI am a bit of a fan of seals, having worked on numerous projects on them. It was the wee mouse.She had been watching from her hole in the wallShe was so tiny, and not strong at all.ldquoHow can you help  sneered the cat, looking at the rest.ldquoWell said the mouse, ldquoI will do my best.So the mouse put her feet around the catrsquos tail, and pulled as hard as she could,While the cat pulled the dog, and the dog pulled the boy, and the boy pulled the girl, and the girl pulled the old woman, and the old woman pulled the old man, and the old man pulled the turnip and this time, it was good!They heaved and heaved, they really triedThis time the turnip came out, ldquoHooray they cried.The old man fell back and knocked over the old woman.The old woman fell back and knocked over the girl.The girl fell back and knocked over the boy.The boy fell back and knocked over the dog.The dog fell back and knocked over the cat.The cat fell back and knocked over the mouse.But then they stood up and looked at the turnip theyrsquod pulled out.ldquoWow, itrsquos absolutely enormous! they all said, with a shout.And so that evening they ate it for tea,In a vegetable soup as tasty as can be.The turnip was enormous, it lasted for weeks,So everything they ate, they ate it with neeps.The dog and cat had their share tooAs did the mouse, who had done the best she could do.She made a dference, despite being so small.Perhaps without her, they couldnrsquot have pulled out, the turnip at all.

title: plans-turn-water-tank-modern-home-given-go-ahead
story: The application received one letter of objection.The approved plans, submitted last year, to turn the more-than--year-old Heugh Reservoir into a liveable property are the second ones to be submitted, after initial ones were withdrawn in .The plans show that the ground floor will consist of a terrace, drawing room, office, guest suite, a fth bedroom with an ensuite bathroom and a plant room, gymnasium and cinema.Upstairs hosts a terrace, the master bedroom and three other bedrooms with all except one having an ensuite bathroom. title: p1-deferrals-u-turn-schools-remain-closed-covid-19
story: Several parents had spoken out in anger after their Primary  deferral funding requests were rejected by the council, which last year had the worst record for approving the applications of any Scottish local authority.This year only two of  applications by parents were approved and of the  refused,  parents appealed.Now the council has said all  cases turned down for funding will be granted the money.However they made it clear the decision was because of the current Covid- pandemic and a review of their policy would be carried out at a later date.One mother told how her children were born two years apart but under the current council policy her youngest son would have had to start P this summer while her oldest, who was born in January, was allowed to defer for a year, was in P.She said: ldquoMy youngest was born at the end of December so they are fully two years apart yet I am not being allowed to defer their start at school and they will be only one year apart in education terms.Current legislation allows parents of children who are born in January and February to automatically receive funding for a delay in starting Primary One until they are five years old.Parents of children born between August and December, who would also start school aged four, can also defer their primary one start for a year but the council can refuse to pay for their nursery care.Last year, East Lothian Council approved  per cent of applications ndash the lowest percentage of any local authority in Scotland. This year the figure fell to less than  per cent.The council also refuses to allow children whose parents opt to keep them home and fund the nursery place themselves to remain in school nurseries.Parents who decide to pay for an additional year of nursery themselves to keep their children out for a year face bills of up to pound, and a hunt for alternative child care places.Another mum who was refused funding said she had initially been supported in her view that her child was too immature to start school by her nursery.But they withdrew that support after pressure from the councilrsquos education department, she said.ldquoThey were told that they couldnrsquot support us because we didnrsquot meet the council policy criteria and withdrew their support, she explained.ldquoOur views meant nothing and the impact on our child meant nothing.And other parents expressed fears that their children were being robbed of nursery experience because they have been in lockdown for some of the vital months they would have had and would have no transition into school.One mum said: Children who start school at -years-old already receive a year less nursery time than those who are older, that has been reduced further by the closure of nurseries.ldquoHow can we ask these young children to go from months at home with their family to suddenly starting primary one with no transition A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoconfirmed they have now agreed to approve all deferral requests for the year ahead.They said: ldquoAs a result of the ongoing closure of schools and nurseries, we have been reviewing applications for deferred entry to P, ahead of session  . Due to the current situation, applications for deferred entry and a further funded year have now been approved. Following the full, national implementation of the expansion of early learning and childcare, we will carry out a review of our wider policy on deferred entry.Thank you for reading this story. title: community-rallies-round-support-salvation-army

title: yacht-club-takes-measures-help-stay-afloat
story: The yachts should have been craned into the harbour at the start of April and the committee had an ldquoanxious pre-season discussion to figure out safe ways to continue activities as the coronavirus crisis started to unfold.After the full lockdown, with the boats still on dry land, members have been using Skype on a near weekly basis to plan how to keep the club thriving for the foreseeable and long-term future.Former commodore Mark McClelland has urged members to take part in an online sailing race game called Virtual Regatta.One club member will be asked to take part in a Virtual Regatta e-championship against players from other Scottish clubs and then go on to a UK-wide competition.While playing the game, Fisherrow Yacht Clubparticipants also take part in a virtual Friday Night Bar get-together, enjoying a tipple in their own homes while connected to other participants through Zoom.One of the biggest losses to the club programme is the start-of-the season event called Discover Sailing, formerly known as Push the Boat Out, which was due to take place this Saturday, May .Inez Visser, club spokesperson, said: ldquoIt should have been an open day for non-members to try sailing and to look around the facilities in the club premises.ldquoDiscover Sailing has been the most important means to recruit new members in the last few years.ldquoFYC hopes to be able to recreate something similar later in the summer while taking into account necessary hygiene requirements.She explained: ldquoMany FYC members can sail their dinghies or yachts solo or with family members so, from that aspect, sailing can resume as soon as is permitted.ldquoIn addition,local members can come to the beach already dressed to go out on the water, this would free up space in the changing facilities for those who travel from further away.ldquoCurrently, the biggest challenge is figuring out a way to crew the club safety and race committee power boats without breach of the contamination guidelines.ldquoHowever, many resourceful solutions have been devised to protect people from contamination so FYC is hopeful a solution for watersports can be found soon.She added: ldquoWhile not sailing, the committee has been looking at research information published by the sailing umbrella body, Royal Yachting Association , which has analysed age demographics and water participation in general in the last few years.ldquoUsing the information from RYA, the club is looking forward to how its current activities and club facilities, especially club-owned boats, can be dferently managed to suit the needs of the next generation of sailors.ldquoThis includes not only Generations X, Y and Z, but also third age sailors, as the research highlighted that sailing is well suited to older people because the physical demands are not as great as many other sports.ldquoAt this time, FYC is ever mindful that the club premises are a resource, not only for the sailing club, but for other users such as the Musselburgh Athletics Club runners, Eskmuthe Rowing Club, sea cadets, Fisherrow Harbour and Seafront Association and the Cooking Club.!In addition, there are one-off users such as the Musselburgh Festival beach ride out guests and British Divers Marine Le Rescue training day volunteers.ldquoAll of the users have had their activities impacted and we hope that, as soon as possible, they too will be able resume.Thank you for reading this story. title: superhero-primary-school-teacher-message-difference
story: Alison Blevins, a primary four teacher at the school, posted a welcome back message on social media after the Easter holidays.It read: ldquoWelcome back to the summer term. Please donrsquot feel any pressure to complete work in what are challenging circumstances. Irsquod sooner you went outside and enjoyed the good weather. See you in our virtual classroom ready to be curious, positive, successful and respectful.Attached to the message was a picture of Alison as a superhero, with a cape and buildings drawn around her on the ground in chalk.Two days later she shared a lsquofun Friday challengersquo and asked her pupils to dress up as their favourite superhero.She dressed up as Spiderman and her son took several pictures of her climbing and hanging from ious buildings.Alison, who lives in a bungalow, said her son stood on top of a flat piece of roof to take the images ndash but stressed that she doesnrsquot recommend people try the same at home!Inspiration for the pictures came from an art project she did with her primary four class last year, which saw them lie on the ground, draw around their head, then stand back up and add something to the drawing such as a hat or crazy hair.Then the pupil would lie back down and take a photograph. Other ideas for her pictures came from the social media site Pinterest.Alison said: ldquoItrsquos just a dferent spin on it and Irsquom trying to engage with the pupils as much as possible, really. Itrsquos easy and just a bit of fun.One drawing for an image can take as long as a couple of hours to complete. They are also planned out on a piece of paper to make sure they will fit into the space.While some pictures are based on the topic being looked at that week, others, such as her Spiderman picture, are for entertainment.Alison said: ldquoPeople have responded really well. Itrsquos a dferent way of getting in contact with the children and keeping them engaged in their learning.She hopes to post at least one picture a week.Thank you for reading this story.
