title: community-resilience-can-turn-help-dirleton-dunbar-east-linton-east-lammermuir-gullane-north-berwick
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at six of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Dirleton Castle.G Laird and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.DirletonTHE Dirleton Area Resilience Teamcontinues to serve its community, with requests to pick up shopping and prescriptions still coming in.It has also launched a new booking system to allow it to better serve its community and protect its volunteers.Its essentials community larder continues to flourish and has seen an entertainment section added.It now stocks books, CDs, DVDs and board games, with sections for both adults and children.Generous donations continue to be made of special food items such as crumbles, bakery treats and soups.DART is working with both the Saltire and Hi Awards, youth volunteer programmes that have allowed the group to include volunteering activities for young people.The Saltire Award is available for young people aged -.It is a nationally credited award that goes towards Scottish Credit and Qualications Framework .Volunteers will be allowed to be a part of DART and help complete requests such as delivering leaflets and fulfilling customer orders.The Hi Awards are for children aged five to . DART will be offering children between these ages at-home volunteering opportunities, such as letter writing and art, which will be sent to those self-isolating and shielding in the village.David Tait, lead co-ordinator for DART, said: ldquoWe now have a great opportunity for the youth in our community to feel part of this amazing organisation.ldquoWith the addition of the awards being nationally recognised and accredited, it was a no-brainer to follow through on this opportunity.ldquoIf any of our youth are interested in the Saltire or Hi Awards, please email your enquiry to Dart.Coordinators@outlook.Contact detailsIf you are in need of assistance, contactDART.coordinators@outlookor call .DunbarDunbarA FRIENDLY voice at the other end of the phone is being offered to people on their own during lockdown.Community resilience volunteers in Dunbar are urging people to get in touch evenit is simply for a chat.The townrsquos volunteers are already offering a range of services, including collecting shopping and prescriptions.In addition, there is also a chance for people to simply talk to someone. George Robertson, a member of the townrsquos community council and chairman of the Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership , stressed the importance of the service.He said: ldquoIt is a really important aspect to the whole thing. I think it will become increasingly important as people get a bit stir crazy.ldquoObviously, a lot of people have friends and family nearby but there are quite a few who do not.ldquoWe need to be conscious that sometimes they are reluctant to ask for help.ldquoWe need to be vigilant for anyone looking for help so we can give a bit of TLC, support, help or a friendly voice on the end of the phone.George has been at the heart of the resilience efforts in the town. Dunbar, along with neighbouring West Barns, has been split into dferent sections, with a lead volunteer in each of the areas.The lead volunteers for the nine clusters ndash Shore and Harbour Group High Street, Parsonspool to Kings Court West End to Countess Road Belhaven and Kirk Park West Barns and the Beveridge Row development Queenrsquos Road and the new housing developments Hallhill, Kellie Road and to the railway line Brodie Road east and north to the railway line and Brodie Road west and north to the railway line ndash have an online meeting each fortnight to checkthere are any issues.George said: ldquoWe are still getting regular requests for shopping, prescriptions and the like.ldquoThere are also a few people who just ring up for a chat.ldquoThat is all ticking along quite nicely.Attention is also turning to how the community copes when lockdown restrictions are relaxed.A number of volunteers willto work as businesses reopen but George was confident that Dunbar and West Barns would continue to be there for people in need.He previously had to draw up a reserve list for volunteers when the coronavirus pandemic started and said there would be enough people to continue to offer support.Contact detailsFor more information, go to Dunbar and District Coronavirus Community Helpers at facebook groups  or Dunbar Community Council at facebook Dunbar CommunityCouncilEast Linton. Picture: Google MapsDunpenderSHOPPING and prescriptions continue to be collected for residents in East Linton and surrounding villages.The Dunpender community resilience team, like many across the county, is offering a iety of services to help people in need during the coronavirus crisis.Judith Priest, chairwoman of the villagersquos community council, said things remained quiet but they were thereanyone was in need of assistance.Contact detailsInformation relating to the coronavirus is available on the Tyninghame Village Hall website ndash tyninghamevillagehall.org.uk ndash as well as on eastlinton.uk.Last month, a flyer was delivered to each home in the area, which offered assistance in terms of shopping, prescriptions or people looking to talk to someone.For more information, call   and  .Stenton.kim traynor and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.East LammermuirTEAMS of volunteers are keeping in touch with each other throughout East Lothian to ensure they are helping people the best they can.Resilience groups have been set up in towns and villages throughout the county during the coronavirus outbreak.Volunteers have come forward to help vulnerable members of the community with any assistance they need.Chris Bruce, chairman of East Lammermuir Community Council, said they were continuing to work together.The community council covers villages including Spott, Stenton, Innerwick and Oldhamstocks.Mr Bruce said: ldquoThere is a pretty good network of email contact, and people follow up with phone callsthere is something particular.ldquoIt is right across East Lothian and is really good.Contact detailsMore information on the help available in the East Lammermuir area is available from the grouprsquos website, eastlammermuircommunitycouncil.org.uk, which also contains a list of the community councillors.Gullane. Picture: Google MapsGullaneA NEW website has been set up to provide people in Gullane with the latest information relating to the coronavirus.The Gullane Resilience Team, made up of volunteers from throughout the village, have been working hard since the outbreak of restrictions due to the global pandemic.Now, a dedicated website has been set up to keep people up-to-date.A spokesman for the villagersquos resilience team said: ldquoThe Gullane Resilience Team have continued to serve the community but have noticed a settling down of demand.ldquoLorna Scott, our co-ordinator, has worked extremely hard and is developing the village hub for the distribution of food, the exchange of DVDs and childrenrsquos games every Tuesday, noon to pm, and Friday, .am to am.ldquoSeveral face shields were donated by Alun Joseph and were passed on to the Gullane Medical Centre and the Muirfield care home.ldquoBoth have reported that they are delighted with them.ldquoA new website, GullaneRT, has been set up which contains all the information regarding how our resources are being deployed and the services that can be provided by the team.Contact detailsFor more information, visit www.gullanert or contact the team on GullaneRteam@gmail or by telephoning  .North Berwick.William Starkey and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.North BerwickNORTH Berwick Day Centre may be closed to its members due to the coronavirus crisis, but it is making sure they are being looked after in their homes.Some  of the day centrersquos  members are receiving sandwich lunches.The centre was established  years ago to improve the quality of le for older people who live independently in and around North Berwick.Normally, members would be brought to the centre by its own specially adapted bus once or twice a week.Now, its nine staff are delivering  lunches, five days a week, and all members are also getting free copies of the East Lothian Courier, thanks to the North Berwick resilience group fund.Care assistant Lisa Robertson said a lot of members were getting their lunch every day and those celebrating birthdays were also getting a special treat.In the past eight weeks, five members have received sweet treats to celebrate their birthdays, with the most recent being a -year-old woman.The Day Centre is also handing out quizzes, games and jigsaws to members, as well as having a chat on doorsteps ndash at a safe distance ndash where possible.Lisa said so far all of the centre members have stayed in good health but they are lonely and missing meeting other people.A team of around  volunteers are contacting members by telephone to have a chat and also find outany other help is needed.Meanwhile, North Berwick Community Councilrsquos resilience group fund is being used to help volunteers get ready-made meals delivered to vulnerable residents in the town three days per week.Community council chair Judy Lockhart has arranged for voluntary organisation Home-Start East Lothian to provide two-course meals at a cost of pound. a day, and is using the fund to subsidise them for people wanting a meal every day of the week.As a result, someone wanting seven meals a week will only have to pay pound.The resilience fund can also offer financial assistance to those who need money to pay for these meals.Contact detailsPeople wishing to sign up for the service should story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at six of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Garvald.M J Richardson and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.GarvaldCOMMUNITY spirit has been praised in a rural part of East Lothian which is tackling the coronavirus.Garvald and Morham Community Council was one of the first to produce an emergency resilience plan, with the Garvald Emergency Resilience Team also being established.Since then, a leaflet has been hand delivered to each of the properties, with information also put online to keep people up-to-date with what is happening.Penny Short, co-ordinator of the Garvald Emergency Resilience Team, noted there were a number of issues they had to overcome, including the remoteness of some people living in the area.She said: ldquoBefore the coronavirus epidemic and subsequent lockdown hit we had already hand delivered a leaflet to every address in our ward explaining who we were and what the team could do, so that everyone in our area knew who to contactthey needed any help.ldquoOur team members have a WhatsApp Group and we keep in touch through that.ldquoSocial media has been a blessing through this time of social distancing!ldquoOnce lockdown was in place I set up a private Facebook page called Garvald Community which is for residents only.ldquoThis is a safe, supportive place where people can ask for help or assistance and hopefully find helpful advice and information such as messages from the government or information on food deliveries.ldquoInformation on food deliveries is pretty important as Garvald doesnrsquot have any shopsand for people who are self-isolating or shielding these food deliveries are essential.ldquoWe contacted ious food suppliers and co-ordinated delivery days and then passed on the details to the villagers.However, it is not just through social media that the group has reached out to people.An online form, which people can fill in outlining how they need assistance, is available on the villagersquos website.Penny added: ldquoWe are aware of any vulnerable people in our area and we are connected with our residents ndash whether through the Garvald Community Facebook page, the website or the villagersquos Neighbourhood Watch Scheme.ldquoBecause we are pretty remote and used to being cut off in bad weather our community is already pretty resilient and has always been supportive to everyone in the village.ldquoBut our wonderful community spirit has never been more evident than right now as everyone has come together to help each other and provide support with shopping, collecting prescriptions, offers of dog walking and other ways to help each other.ldquoWe have recently launched a group to make face masks for locals and lsquoscrubs bagsrsquo for NHS and care workers.ldquoNot for the first time I am so grateful to stay in Garvald and so proud of our fantastic community."Contact detailsFor more information, go to www.garvald.org.ukGford. Picture: Google MapsGfordGIFFORD volunteers this week trialled a new Soup And A Smile delivery service as they took hot lentil soup, a buttered roll and a fruit scone to households where there are older residents living alone.The plan is to provide lunch one day a week, as well as catch up with residents while observing social distancing rules.Nicola Goddard, from Lanterne Rouge cafeacute, offered her services to support the volunteer activity, which is provided free to the households.A spokesperson for Gford Community Council said: ldquoThe feedback is already very positive both regarding the fabulous quality of the food and the concept.ldquoOur delivery team worked quickly and observed all protocols to deliver the food to households. Wersquore gathering more feedback as we look to provide this on a weekly basis.This week, the team has also been sourcing face coverings for volunteers, to offer them extra confidence when undertaking tasks on behalf of households.Lanterne Rouge donated a supply of lsquobuffsrsquo and local resident and designer Ellie Thomson is making the coverings from her home.The community council said a request for cotton fabric, thread and elastic generated a fantastic response and they are currently trying to source additional elastic.They have also written to Homes For Le Housing Partnership, which oversees social housing flats in the village, after discovering families living there were unable to use their drying greens as gardens.They said: ldquoWe are very lucky in Gford to have a lot of open green space surrounding us.ldquoWe became aware through some tenants in social housing flats that they are unable to use drying greens as garden space for their children.ldquoWe have written to Homes For Le to ask that this situation is revisited so all children can have access to safe outdoor space on their doorstep.ldquoWe received a positive response from the organisation and hope that the guidance can be claried to benefit families in the village.Contact detailsAnyone needing help can contact: Jo Allen, GCC chair, on   or ChairGfordCC@gmail Adam White, GCC vice chair, on   or adamjswhite@outlook Wendy Ferguson, GCC treasurer, on   or wendyferguson.wf@gmail Aniko Schuetz Bradwell, minister, on   or aschuetzbradwell@churchofscotland.org.ukHaddingtonHaddingtonRESILIENCE volunteers are looking to the future to ensure people continue to receive assistance once lockdown restrictions are relaxed.A squad of volunteers in Haddington have been helping with everything from collecting food and prescriptions to walking dogs and simply providing someone for people to talk to.However, the resilience team is now planning for the future to ensure there are still plenty of volunteers available as lockdown is eased.Chris McEwan, vice-chairman of the townrsquos community council, has been at the heart of the resiliency efforts.He said: ldquoWe are now starting to put plans together for coming out of quarantine.ldquoFor a lot of us in the coming weeks, we will be coming out of lockdown but for our elderly residents they will probably still be in lockdown.ldquoWe are starting to plan to make sure everybody is taken care of post lockdown.Currently, many of the volunteers are off their work and able to help throughout the town.However, as businesses reopen and peopleto work, it reduces the amount of free time people have.Chris said it was important to ensure there were still volunteers available to help people who continued to be at home.The group experienced an increase in calls in the last week, with the community council vice-chairman putting it down to many people reaching the end of the month in terms of their wages.He said: ldquoFor some folk it was the end of the month and we were getting an increase in calls about food.ldquoWe have done a few things over the weekend and a couple of things to make sure people have good food, that they are covered and they are not starving themselves.Chris praised the efforts of Our Community Kitchen, who are based in the townrsquos bowling club.The team of volunteers are delivering hot meals to people throughout the town to ensure no-one is going hungry.One other issue Chris pointed to was the increased need in terms of help with gardening.He added: ldquoWith the rain and sunshine over the past week, peoplersquos gardens have started growing.ldquoWe have got in touch with some gardeners, who are going out to help people this week.Contact detailsFor more information, go to www.haddingtoncc.org.uk or call   , between am and pm.Macmerry. Picture: Google MapsMacmerry and GladsmuirTHE Macmerry and Gladsmuir Community Resilience Team are encouraging local residents to continue making pom poms, and are on the lookout for more supplies.In the past two weeks,  craft packs containing equipment necessary to make the pom poms have been distributed, with a number of adults joining in alongside the villagesrsquo children.Stevie Sutherland, one of the resilience co-ordinators, told the Courier that volunteers have put ribbons up along the school gates for people to hang their finished pom poms from.He said: ldquoWersquove had about  packs handed out already and people have started making them.ldquoPeople are encouraged to go along to the school and tie their pom poms to the ribbons.He added: ldquoSince itrsquos started itrsquos become quite colourful and is really nice to see.ldquoThe whole point is to show off community support it will also show and encourage people who are from Macmerry or travelling through that we are supporting frontline workers, whether that be from the NHS, emergency service workers or supermarket staff.ldquoWe are trying to bring back that feel-good factor into the villages, when all we seem to have is bad news.One resident has decided to hang plastic balls of dferent colours outside her house as part of the project.Anyone willing to donate wool, of any quality although double knit is preferred, or anyone needing assistance is asked to call  .Collection or pick up of wool donations can also be arranged.Meanwhile, the resilience team were joined by a couple of new volunteers in the past week, and they will help to deliver the continuing resilience effort.Stevie said the resilience group have put together a contingency plan, should the virusin the future, which will allow the effort to start back up again more quickly and smoothly.He said: ldquoWersquove put a kind of plan in place, forthis all goes away then comes back again.ldquoWe now have an admin system that could be started upneeded.Contact detailsMore information is available on the resilience grouprsquos Facebook and Twitter pages, atfacebook groups   andtwitter MacmerryTeamPencaitland. Picture: Google MapsPencaitlandTHE response from residents in Pencaitland and its surrounding area to an appeal for volunteers has been described as ldquophenomenal by community council chairman Ralph Averbuch.Before lockdown had even been introduced, Pencaitland Community Council was preparing for what was coming with an early call for help.Now they have  volunteers working in a resilience network of support for the communityrsquos most vulnerable families and residents.Ralph said: ldquoOn March , it was already looking like we were approaching unprecedented events in modern times.ldquoIt was still a week away from local schools being closed and social distancing really kicking in however, unprecedented times require unprecedented measures and in Pencaitland and District that involved a call for volunteers.ldquoWe needed to be ready, and quickly, for whatever was coming.ldquoMost calls for community participation in ordinary times generate next to no response.ldquoPeople are busy with their own lives and family work concerns so lsquocommunityrsquo, for most, almost always takes a back seat.ldquoYet, when the call went out for volunteers, the response was nothing short of phenomenal.ldquoWithin  hours we had  people signed up and ready to do whatever needed to be done.ldquoFrom this start, we were able to begin a process of organising volunteers into geographic clusters, each with their own lead co-ordinators.ldquoNothing like this has happened in any of our letimes, yet, when the situation really demanded that people step up and be counted, there was no shortage of volunteers willing and able to help, from people in their teens to those in their s.ldquoWe are now a resilience network of . Had I been asked at the start how many people would come forward Irsquod have thought Irsquod be able to count them on one hand.ldquoThe good news is when itrsquos really important and people know it, there is no shortage of volunteers wanting to help solve our problems.Contact detailsAnyone living in or around the Pencaitland area and seeking assistance, or just wanting to help out, in the first instance can call Community Council chair Ralph on   or email him at covid@pencaitland.org.Additionally, Pencaitland  District Coronavirus Emergency Helpers have a Facebook page ndash facebook groups   ndash where you can get in touchyou want to help with the massive volunteer effort.Tranent. Picture: Google MapsTranent and ElphinstoneTRANENT and Elphinstone Community Council is starting to think about how it will continue delivering its resilience effort once lockdown restrictions start to be relaxed.Member Mike Falconer is the grouprsquos single point of contact and is overseeing the local resilience effort.He told the Courier that, once restrictions begin to lt, people will still need support so the resilience effort will still be needed, something he said could be described as ldquocontingency planning.He said: ldquoWe canrsquot just stop the need is still going to be there.ldquoThe lt of restrictions is going to be gradual [rather than all at once] and we need to think how we are going to manage and maintain the resilience effort and some sort of support.He added that there is not a plan in place, as such, but the community council ldquohas got its eye on it.Meanwhile, it is business as usual and residents who need assistance continue to get the help they need.Mike said: ldquoItrsquos exactly the same and we are carrying on doing what we are doing, delivering food, walking dogs and picking up prescriptions.ldquoWersquove got a routine established and are just carrying on delivering it until we are told to stop.The resilience effort is also helping Fundamental Foods and the Pennypit Trust with food deliveries, as well as assisting with its school hub effort.Contact detailsThose who need assistance can call   or email tranentemergencyresponse@gmail

title: community-resilience-can-turn-help-cockenzie-port-seton-humbie-east-west-saltoun-bolton-longniddry-musselburgh-prestonpans
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at five of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Cockenzie and Port Seton. Picture: Google MapsCockenzie and Port SetonTHE resilience team in Cockenzie  Port Seton continue to help local residents, and more than pound, has been donated to the cause by iniduals and groups since lockdown began.The resilience effort is being led by Cockenzie  Port Seton Community Council, whose chairman, Bryan Hickman, said: ldquoPeople have been so generous and the money is being used to purchase food.Some of the grouprsquos volunteers are asking for donations of wool, to make blankets which will be given to the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh and used for premature babies.To donate items, contact Cockenzie  Port Seton Community Council via email at cockenzieandportseton@hotmail.The resilience group has received a donation from the Walk With Scott Foundation and will deliver craft activity packs alongside its breakfast packs on Wednesdays, helping to keep local residents entertained while at home.To mark VE Day and allow residents to celebrate in lockdown, afternoon tea boxes consisting of items such as sandwiches, scones, cakes and tea will be delivered.Bryan is also keen to get copies of the Courier delivered to elderly and vulnerable residents, as groups in Haddington and North Berwick are doing.The community councilrsquos resilience team are also sending out hot meals and providing food packs to local children who would usually receive free school meals.This is being run from the Port Seton Centre, supported by centre staff.So far,  lunches and  breakfast packs are going out every day.More than , meals are going out to the local community every week.Last week, the centre started receiving a delivery from FareShare, a charity that delivers surplus food from supermarkets to charities and organisations for those in need.Contact detailsAnyone who needs assistance can call the resilience emergency number on  .East Saltoun. Picture: Google MapsHumbie, East and West Saltoun, and BoltonRESIDENTS of four rural villages are being reminded help is there for themthey need it.Contacts have been set up in Humbie, East and West Saltoun, and Bolton to offer people assistance during the coronavirus pandemic.Shena Jamieson, who lives in Bolton, told the Courier it had been reasonably quiet in terms of the number of calls but stressed they were there to help.She said: ldquoPeople should ring us.ldquoDonrsquot feel that you are being a nuisance or wonder whether it is the right person.ldquoWe can always put you in touch with the right person.Contact detailsPeople in Bolton should contact Shena Jamieson on   or by email at shenajamieson@aol.East Saltoun residents can contact Buffy Neilson on   or buffyneilson@yahoo.In West Saltoun, Derek Smith is the point of contact on   or by emailing coruisk@gmail.Finally, in Humbie, people are encouraged to call Margo Hodge on   or email humbiehelp@gmailLongniddry. Picture: Google MapsLongniddryITrsquoS business as usual for the resilience effort in Longniddry which is being led by the local church and supported by Longniddry Community Council.SheilaJamieson said she is still receiving some queries, such as people with toothache asking the best place to get help.She added that there have not been many shopping requests, as a lot of residents are getting their food through online deliveries.Sheila said: ldquoAlthough we do have quite a lot of older people, we are quite fortunate to have a great community.ldquoVolunteers are also helping their neighbours and friends along with enquiries as they come in.ldquoItrsquos pretty steady and we are just going on as normal.One Longniddry resident has started offering a dogwalking service for those unable to take their pooch on its daily stroll.Those interested should contact Danni Anderson on Facebook.Volunteers are happy to pick up prescriptions, though the local pharmacy offers a delivery service to those aged  and over.Contact detailsThose who need any help or assistance are asked to call Sheila Jamieson on  .Musselburgh. Picture: Google MapsMusselburghRESILIENT Musselburgh has nearly hit the  mark with the number of volunteers who have joined its emergency efforts during the Covid- pandemic.The co-ordinating team have now settled into their new base at the Musselburgh East Community Learning Centre, after their recent move from Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School.Distribution of food and prescriptions to the communities of Musselburgh, Wallyford, Whitecraig and Old Craighall is continuing.Local residents are being supported through referrals from the East Lothian Council Contact Centre and callsto the Resilient Musselburgh dedicated phone number on  .Last week alone,  preschool lunch packs,  meals and  lunches were distributed.Up until last Friday,  soup and sandwich deliveries were made thanks to the Mercat Grill in Whitecraig, which started the initiative on April .Musselburgh Area Partnership, working in partnership with Hickory, started distributing meals on April  and, so far, they have provided  meals to vulnerable people in the local community.Irene Tait, chairperson of Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council, who is co-ordinating the volunteer response, said: ldquoIt is so heartening to see the willingness and effort given to the community by the volunteers.ldquoThey have happily gone over and above by uplting and delivering repeat prescriptions from ious locations, including uplts from outside Musselburgh, and are continuing to deliver emergency food packs and pre-school lunches.ldquoWithout them the community response would not happen.Contact detailsThe Resilient Musselburgh dedicated support number is  .Prestonpans. Picture: Google MapsPrestonpansPRESTONPANS Community Council has established a hardship fund for people who are struggling as the lockdown continues.Community council chairman Brian Weddell said last week had been the busiest yet for the resilience team, with volunteers managing to deliver leaflets throughout the Pans advertising the Scotmid free shopping delivery service, and several volunteers now doing daily dog walks for local people self isolating.More of the volunteers are also helping the work at the Pennypit Pantry by collecting groceries being donated by local supermarkets and delivering meals to local people.Last week, the Pantry provided  meals to a mix of elderly residents who are shielding and many families looking after young children currently off school.While demand for support has been high, anyone needing help should contact the Pennypit Pantry on   or email lornabellany@gmailThe hardship fund has been established for people finding it increasingly dficult as the lockdown continues, and anyone needing help should telephone   or email prestonpansresilience@gmailRegular information is also posted on both the Prestonpans Community Council Facebook page or their dedicated Prestonpans Resilience Facebook page.Brian said: ldquoOur resilience team are also grateful for the support we are receiving from Sandy Baptie and Kevin Sewell in East Lothian Councilrsquos Resilient Communities team, who send out daily updates which provide useful information on what is happening in other resilience teams and the additional support that is available.Contact detailsIf anyone needs help, they should telephone   or emailprestonpansresilience@gmail

title: must-return-fairer-world-says-mp
story: MINDS are turning to le post-coronavirus, though itrsquoll still be a while before lockdown is even partially lted. But some of the enforced changes have suited some.Irsquove a few friends nearing retirement age and, enjoying the change in pace of le, have decided to retire early. It doesnrsquot suit everyone and itrsquos not available for many but, for those to whom it does apply, I say good luck.But there are other aspects that apply to us all. The Irish President, Michael D Higgins, made a remarkable speech about how both a better country and a fairer world need to come from this. Those sentiments and that ambition must apply here, as well as across the Irish Sea.When this is over, itrsquos about rewarding fairly those who have, not just throughout this crisis but always, worked hard in dficult circumstances.Itrsquos decent pay and conditions, as much as applause, that NHS staff, carers and council workers deserve. Despite the rhetoric about all of us being in this together, the poor have been suffering the most and that too must change.As well as in our economy and society though, the change must also be in our natural environment. Theof wildle has been joyful and the improvement in air quality a revelation.The latterrsquos something wersquove often taken for granted but for those with a lung or heart problem itrsquos a daily concern.The images of pollution fading across countries is astonishing but the freshness wersquore feeling in our lungs is something we need to retain.We canrsquot simply go back to le the way it was. When the coronavirus crisis is over, the climate change crisis will remain.We need to cherish the improvements that have come about, but remember the huge challenges that still exist, in ensuring our planetrsquos habitable for future generations.It wonrsquot be either easy or simple but the sacrices made by so many and the limited pleasures wersquove had as a result of it, must be a spur to deliver that better country and fairer world.

title: former-power-station-site-become-covid-19-testing-centre
story: East Lothian Council has confirmed that the former Cockenzie Power Station site will be opened and operated by the military as part of the UK Governments Covid- testing programme.No date for when it will start operations has been revealed but it is likely to be within the next week as testing is ramped up as part of plans to ease the current lockdown.It will be the first Covid- testing site of its kind in East Lothian, where an assessment centre has also been operating in Musselburgh since the start of April.The site, which was bought by the local authority from ScottishPower and is currently being marketed for economic investment, was offered up as a potential testing location by the council.The unit will be managed and staffed by military personnel, who would be responsible for its safe operation.Military staff will make appropriate use of PPE and no equipment will be left on site whilst the facility is closed.The council said it expects the facility to operate as a self-contained, drive-through facility. People will remain in their vehicle whilst being tested. Initially, it is understood it would operate over two, three-day periods.Tom Reid, the councils head of infrastructure, said: ldquoWe were asked to identy a potentially suitable site for a drive-through, mobile testing facility to be located."The former Cockenzie Power Station site was identied as a site which could be operated safely by military personnel."This facility would enable key workers who are self-isolating due to them or household members displaying symptoms to undergo testing, which is a vital component of the national response to tackling Covid-."East Lothian Council will continue to play its part and work with partners locally and nationally in dealing with the challenges posed by the emergency.The facility will provide tests for key workers who are self-isolating due to them or household members displaying symptoms.It is understood key workers and their family members will be eligible for testing.Key workers who are, or have a family member who is, symptomatic, can sign up via thehttps:self-referral.test-for-coronavirus.service.gov.uk portal.Cockenzie power stations famous twin chimneys were demolished in a controlled explosion in September, , two years after it had closed. The power station had opened in .

title: costa-coffee-starbucks-mcdonalds-get-green-light-reopen-drive-thrus
story: Ahead of an anticipated relaxation of the lockdown rules, the Environment Secretary has said drive-thru restaurants such as McDonaldrsquos are ldquomade for social distancing.At the Downing Street press conference on Friday, George Eustice said it was safe for takeaway food shops to reopen.Many familiar high street chains including McDonaldrsquos, Greggs and KFC chose to shut their doors during the lockdown.What did the Environment Secretary say When asked about fast-food stores reopening, Mr Eustice said: ldquoI think our view is that probably a McDonaldrsquos drive-thru is made for the social distancing situation we are in, in that people do not leave their car, they place their order and someone passes a bag of food to them at the end through a kiosk.Unlike many other businesses, fast-food outlets were not mandated to close during the lockdown.Some chains have begun to reopenSome restaurants have begun the process of reopening, with KFC opening around  of its branches for delivery or drive-thru.McDonaldrsquos has conducted trials on reopening stores, with  restaurants opening for deliveries from next week.Askedoutlets could have stayed open during the crisis, Mr Eustice said: ldquoWhile clearly restaurants and pubs had to close, we were quite keen to keep that capacity to be able to do takeaway food for people.He suggested reduced footfall in town centres, staff anxiety and a sense of what was ldquosocially acceptable given the stay-at-home message had led to places such as McDonaldrsquos and KFC closing.Mr Eustice added: ldquoI think it is quite possible for these venues to reopen and reopen safely, we never mandated that they should close.ldquoI think some of those food-to-go businesses will probably be seeking to learn lessons from what supermarkets have done as they consider tentatively reopening.New safety measures have been introduced at food outletsBefore reopening, the McDonaldrsquos restaurants will be deep cleaned, while new safety measures will be introduced such as Perspex screens and floor markings.Staff will also receive protective equipment, such as non-medical grade face masks, and have their temperatures taken with ldquocontactless thermometers before shts.Earlier this month Greggs pulled back on plans to reopen its first sites to the public next week over fears it could attract crowds.The highly popular bakery chain announced it would carry out the opening trial behind closed doors over fears customers will flock in large numbers.

title: itv-reveal-run-episodes-emmerdale-coronation-street
story: It comes after the number of shows broadcast each week were cut back to make the bank of recorded episodes last longer after production on both soaps was suspended in March.When are episodes set to run out ITV sayEmmerdale will run out of episodes at the end of May, while Coronation Street will run out of episodes after June.What will happen when filming resumes No clear date has been confirmed as to when Coronation Street and Emmerdale would go back into production, but both shows couldto screens with older cast members absent and actors six feet apart, ITV boss Kevin Lygo has said.The director of television at the channel said he is anxious to get the soaps back into production because ldquoITV without soaps is barely ITV, adding: ldquoThey are terribly important to get back up and running.Speaking at the Edinburgh Television Festival, which took place online this year, he said: ldquoThey are working really hard now as to how, when,and when restrictions are lted a bit, how can we make the soaps in a safe way.ldquoThey are being inventive and creative about rejigging storylines, I think we have got to accept there will be no more than two people talking in a room, and looking at ways of shooting where people donrsquot appear to be six feet apart.He said the broadcaster is also investigating whether testing for coronavirus among the cast and crew is also an option, saying: ldquoThe zoom, the lockdown programming that has been on air all over the place, I donrsquot think with drama and soap, you canrsquot expect themhellip you need make-up, you need wardrobe, people will not be able to stay six feet apart and so how can that be done in a safe way.He added: ldquoWe wonrsquot go back in shooting until we are convinced it is safe, we donrsquot want to put any of our staff, our cast and our crew, at risk.ldquoSome people who are in a dangerous zone, by age or health reasons, they wonrsquot be there, Irsquom sure, for a time.ldquoI donrsquot want Ken Barlowto get sick on my watch. We will be very careful and mindful about that sort of thing.Lygo said that while viewership is up in daytime, it is not up in peak time and he is worried about shedding viewers over the summer when the schedule is filled with repeats.He said this is why he is particularly anxious to get the soaps back on air, adding: ldquoI donrsquot want anyone who has been watching the soaps for years thinking lsquoOh I have done without it, maybe Irsquoll detox and Irsquoll get some le backrsquo.ldquoNo. Please donrsquot do that. Please keep watching the soaps. Wersquoll just have to be better at what we do.

title: ryanairs-new-passenger-rules-airline-plans-restart-some-flights-july
story: The company said the measure is subject to government restrictions on flights within the EU being lted and ldquoeffective public health measures being put in place at airports.Heres what you title: east-lothian-council-racing-june
story: Groundstaff at the townrsquos award-winning racecourse, who have been furloughed, will temporarily resume work this month to prepare the track for the anticipated fixture.Bill Farnsworth, general manager, said that the racecourse was using the next few weeks to prepare after the UK Government said no sporting events woulduntil June  and the Scottish Government continued lockdown until the end of May.He said: ldquoThe British Horseracing Industry has already done much work on the operational plan for the resumption of horseracing in the UK.ldquoWe will therefore use the forthcoming weeks to finalise the plan for ato racing at Musselburgh, hopefully in June, however horseracing will only resume at Musselburgh when it is safe to do so and with the full support of the UK and Scottish Governments.Mr Farnsworth said that racingrsquoswould be under strict restrictions and behind closed doors, similar to what is already happening in France and Germany.He said the hope is that Musselburgh can resume its schedule fixture list with a race on June , which had already been in its diary.He said: ldquoIf horseracing resumes in June, we hope to stage Musselburghrsquos scheduled fixture on Saturday thJune butthe advice is that June is too early to stage horseracing in Scotland, we will wait until for the appropriate time and for the greenlight from the UK and Scottish Governments.Horse-racing ed in France this week giving hope to trainers that Britain will not be far behind.A joint letter to Scottish Sports Minister Joe Fitzpatrick, MSP, from East Lothian MP Kenny MacAskill and MPs Allan Dorans, Angela Crawley and Pete Wishart, who represent racecourses in Hanmilton, Ayr and Perth urges a quick restart to racing when safe to do so.It says: ldquoRacing finds itself in a unique position compared to other Scottish sports in that our equine athletes, cherished so highly by those in the industry, have remained in training during thepandemic and will therefore be able to come back on shorter notice than the human athletes inother sports.ldquoWhen it is safe to do so, ato racing is the best way of getting the economic cogs of theindustry turning once more, and kickstart the benefits to the Scottish economy that horseracingbrings, even in a behind closed doors environment.ldquoTherefore, we ask that you please accelerateyour talks with Scottish racing to ensure that a risk managedcan take place as soon aspossible and that ato racing behind closed doors in Scotland does not get unduly delayedcompared to the rest of the United Kingdom.

title: furlough-extended-october-questions-answered
story: But what does it all mean for workers and businesses Heres what you need to know.What will happen to workers on furlough Mr Sunak said they will continue to receive  per centof their pay ndash up to pound, a month ndash until the end of October.This extends the original furlough scheme to eight months since it was launched in March.The Chancellor also said there will be the possibility of part-time s for staff from August, pointing out that manufacturers have been asking for staggered shts to reopen production lines.Are there more details on part-time s and can I take a job where The details will be published later this month, but Mr Sunak stressed to MPs that furloughed workers can take jobs where while on the scheme.Government advice says: ldquoIf your contract allows, you may undertake other employment while your current employer has placed you on furlough, and this will not affect the grant that they can claim under the scheme.However, staff cannot work for their employer while furloughed.Will the Government continue covering the cost The Government will fund the furlough scheme, which has supported seven million jobs at a cost of pound billion a month, until the end of July.After that, companies will be expected to make a contribution to the payments, although the amount workers take home will not fall below the  per cent mark.How much will businesses be expected to pay towards furlough The details will be published later this month, the Chancellor said, but it is likely to be judged on a sector-by-sector basis, similar to the details published on Monday by the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategyfor companies looking to reopen under new ldquoCovid Secure measures.With certain sectors ing to some normality, others, including restaurants and gyms, remain unlikely to reopen fully for several months.Can we expect to see furlough extended beyond October The Government has said it will continue to monitor the situation and is willing to adjust advice accordingly.But Mr Sunak made clear it is unlikely to be extended.He told the Commons: ldquoWe will keep everything under review but my expectation is by thenthe scheme should end. Wersquove stretched and strained to be as generous as possible to businesses and workers, which is why we have made the decision that wersquove made today.The Chancellor added: ldquoBut hellip this scheme is expensive. Itrsquos the right thing to do. The cost of not acting would have been far higher but itrsquos not something that can continue indefinitely into the future. Eight months of total support is a considerable amount of time.Are there any other signicant changes to the furlough scheme More details will come this month, but MPs raised concerns from self-employed workers who pay themselves via idends, asking whether they would be able to receive further support.However, Mr Sunak insisted current support is strong enough.Why is the Government announcing the extension now Under employment laws, companies must start informing any staff they plan to make redundant within  days of any changes.The previous furlough scheme was due to end by July, meaning consultations would need to begin imminently, but the extension to October will address it.

title: mcdonalds-reveal-safety-rules-customers-ahead-gradual-reopening
story: The move comes after announcing a delivery-only service, followed by the reopening of a number of drive-thrus later this month.What are McDonalds doing McDonaldrsquos is to reopen its first  drive-through restaurants as early as next week as it pushes forward with its reopening plans.It comes as fast food rival Subway reopens more than  of its UK stores on Tuesday for delivery and takeaway as it serves customers for the first time since the lockdown.McDonaldrsquos will open its first  pilot restaurants from am on Wednesday, May , for deliveries only.The fast food chain said it intends to begin the next phase of its reopening plans next week by opening  sites in the UK and Ireland for drive-through customers only on Wednesday, May .It said it plans to reopen all of its drive-through sites by early June, in line with Government guidelines.What additional rules will be in place for customers McDonaldrsquos said it will cap the amount customers can spend to pound per car and will ask customers to use contactless payment.This will take place alongside safety measures the chain already announced, such as contactless thermometers for staff, Perspex screens and protective equipment.The company called for customers to be ldquopatient and supportive of staff as sites reopen, warning that service ldquowill not be as quick as you might be used to as workers adjust to the changes.What have McDonalds said Paul Pomroy, McDonaldrsquos chief executive officer for UK and Ireland, said: ldquoThere has been an incredible response to news of our reopening and we know many of you are eager for us to extend our reopening plans at a faster pace.ldquoThe wellbeing of our employees, suppliers and delivery partnersrsquo couriers is my top priority and we will only extend our plans at a pace that enables us to create a safe working environment for our teams.ldquoAs we get accustomed to the new processes and procedures, we will look to reopen more restaurants, for longer hours and reintroduce more menu items.ldquoBut only when I am confident we can do so whilst maintaining the new procedures we have introduced for the protection of our people.What are other food outlets doing Meanwhile, Subway said it has reopened more than  stores on Tuesday, May , in the first phase of its reopening programme.It said the sites have reopened with new operational and social distancing safety measures to protect customers and staff.The chain said customers will be able to have food from these sites delivered via Just Eat, Uber Eats or Deliveroo.Colin Hughes, country director for Subway UK and Ireland, said: ldquoEverybody in our Subway family and the wider communities they serve, has shown great resilience in adapting to these challenging times that we currently find ourselves in.ldquoWe are extremely grateful for their ongoing support in anticipation of this next phase of our gradual reopening, which will enable us to continue to serve our communities and frontline workers, who have helped us all so much in recent weeks.ldquoThe weeks and months ahead will continue to be challenging for everyone and Subway will play its part in supporting the new normal whatever that may look and feel like.

story: Its number  service, which links parts of Musselburgh to the west side of Edinburgh, now sees frequency improved to every  minutes from Monday-Saturday during the day.There is minor timetable changes on the  service which goes from Tranent to Edinburgh through Prestonpans and Musselburgh.On EastCoast Buses, the  service, which goes from Dunbar to Edinburgh through places such as Haddington, Tranent and Wallyford, sees daytime frequency increased to  minutes from Edinburgh to Haddington, the hourly service to and from Dunbar will be maintained.On the  Pencaitland to Edinburgh service, there is a revised timetable to coordinate with the . title: hollywood-stars-appear-outlander-returns-east-lothian
story: Filming for the worldwide hit took place in spring last year but details about what was shot could not be revealed until after its episode had aired.East Linton is no stranger to the Outlander cast and crew as Preston Mill has also been used as a filming location.While Outlander star Sam Heughan ndash who was not in East Linton this time ndash was part of a fundraising campaign which helped raise pound, to repair the millrsquos water wheel.The Mart, formerly a market place for local farmers and traders, is now an arts and events venue. It had been booked for weddings this summer, but these have been delayed until next year due to the coronavirus outbreak.Outlanderrsquos programmersquos location manager contacted Melissa Wearmouth, The Martrsquos site manager, to arrange the filming.Melissa told the Courier: ldquoThey wanted something with our shape of building and were finding it hard to come across.Our building is the last one of its kind in Scotland so is quite unique .ldquoOne of the guys spoke to a friend and mentioned us and then the people from the show got in contact.Crew were there for three weeks to set up equipment for only one dayrsquos filming. Stars including Billy Boyd, of Lord of the Rings fame, Edward Speleers , James Dohertyand Andy Apollowere spotted.Melissa added that The Martrsquos car park was full and there were a lot of people about, such as security, catering and lighting staff.Filming also attracted some fans of the show, who hoped to catch a glimpse of their favourite characters.Work to restore the building, which included laying a new floor and painting the exterior, had just been finished.Melissa said: ldquoThey were pretty easy going. They had to change little things, like laying an old floor.ldquoWe put the new floor on top of the old cobbles and put in a glass centrepiece so you could still see the cobbles in the middle we needed a new floor for events and stuff.ldquoIt took us a long time to restore the building and its original features we tried to keep as many of the older features as possible.ldquo[The Outlander team] put a temporary floor on top so they could have dirt and things like that ndash they needed it to look more like a tavern.The Mart is featured in series five of the show, which is out now on Amazon Prime, at the end of episode two, which was first broadcast on February .Melissa admitted she had not watched the show previously but does now!

title: former-royal-marine-conquers-everest-back-garden
story: Kenny Simm, , climbed a rope and abseiled down it in his garden on the Lennoxlove Estate, near Haddington,  times, completing a total of , metres, the same height as Mount Everest in the Himalayas.He completed his challenge over  hours, starting at am on April  and finishing at am on April .He did not sleep in between but did occasionally stop for refreshment breaks.Kenny said: ldquoI think it was just a spur of the moment thing.ldquoI came up with the idea four days before I started it so didnrsquot do any prior training.ldquoWhen I was with the Marines I went off-shore and saw all these challenges people were doing and thought it would be a good thing to do.ldquoI wanted to do something a bit dferent and a bit special for charity and also to challenge myself.He had a four-metre-long rope attached to the side of his shed that he intended to use for the challenge. . . until the rope snapped during a testing session.Kenny was climbing the rope at the time and fell four metres to the ground but was not badly hurt.He then contacted a friend who came to his house and built an eight-metre-high scaffolding structure in his garden specially for the challenge.Every time he landed on solid ground, he would record his run to make sure he completed the , journeys needed to reach the required distance:  times up and  times down.While the journey down was a simple abseil, Kenny, who used to be on the British bobsleigh team and competed in strongman events, had to pull himself to the top.Kenny, who is originally from Shetland and is dad to seven-year-old Hugo, was a Royal Marine for  years.He now works for Viridor as a mechanical fitter at the Dunbar energy recovery facility.He said: ldquoI think the Royal Marines helped a little bit. Being part of the Marines is like an exclusive club and I had that prior training.He added: ldquoNot sleeping was the hardest bit. When I asked my we about it she said, lsquoYoursquore not going to do thatrsquo.ldquoShe set an alarm every two hours and was checking on me to make sure I was still alive. I made pasta and made sure to keep my food and drink intake up. I had music playing too.ldquoIt was pretty tough, especially the first two hours. I kept thinking lsquowhat kind of challenge is this going to bersquo and wondered how I was going to do it for  hours.ldquoThere was added pressure because we had highlighted it on social media.Kenny is raising money for the NHS who, he says, are ldquodoing amazing work, are ldquorisking their lives and ldquohave never had that [proper] recognition.Hersquos raised almost pound, so far.His mother-in-law Carol Fitzgerald is a retired NHS worker and sister-in-law Karen McQuade works in a coronavirus ward at Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh.Hearing their stories also inspired him.It took Kenny two days to fully recover from his challenge, which gave him blisters and cramps in his arms and legs.He added: ldquoIrsquom glad I did it but I wonrsquot be doing it again.Anyone wishing to donate can do so at www.justgiving fundraising kennysimm-climbeverestfor-nhs

title: veteran-musicians-mark-ve-day-doorsteps
story: Alastair Knowles BEM played the lsquoLast Postrsquo on the bugle from the front door of his Stoneyhill home and pipe major Stewart Braby performed lsquoBattlersquos Orsquoerrsquo at the Mall near his house in Inveresk Road last Friday.Mr Knowles said he was asked by Iain Clark, from Musselburgh, a Depute Lieutenant of East Lothian, to mark the end of the two -minute silence at am that day by ringing the bell at Northesk Church in Musselburgh, which he duly did.Mr Knowles also heard from Bruno Peek, VE Day  Pageant Master, who was keen to keep as much of the national programme going as possible amidst the coronavirus pandemic.The events were arranged to mark the th anniversary of Victory in Europe Day ndash the day celebrating the formal acceptance by the Allies of the Nazisrsquo unconditional surrender of their armed forces, on Tuesday,  May , marking the end of the Second World War in Europe.Buglers and trumpeters were still urged to sound the lsquoLast Postrsquo, as planned, at .pm, and pipers to play lsquoBattlersquos Orsquoerrsquo at pm.Mr Knowles followed his uncle into the Boysrsquo Brigade in the mid-s.Since then he has become a key part of the group, becoming a bugler and leading drummer in the Penicuik and Musselburgh Boysrsquo Brigade Pipe Band.He was Town Champion at the  Riding of the Marches in Musselburgh, before being appointed chairman of the  event.He is also a former president of the Old Musselburgh Club.He received the BEM for services to the community in Musselburgh.Mr Braby, pipe major with the Penicuik  Musselburgh Boysrsquo Brigade Pipe Band, is also pipe major of the massed bands at the Boysrsquo Brigade Beating Retreat at Edinburgh Castle.Mr Knowles said: ldquoLater in the evening my we Lily and I, as our daily exercise outing, took a walk to Northesk, where the third member of the church,Lorraine McBrearty, added her contribution with the singing of lsquoWersquoll Meet Againrsquo only yards from her home on Bridge Street at pm.He added: ldquoIt was a busy but fulfilling day.
