title: cafe offers delivery service help need
story: Staff at the Marie Curie Hospice in Penarth" Café offers delivery service to help those in needCharlotte Court , co-owner of Willmore#s , delivers food parcels ltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtto Llandough lt spangtlt spangt" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentA LOCAL cafeacute has started a regular food delivery service to support frontline staff and their patients who are suffering from Covid- at Llandough Hospital.The co-owners of Willmorersquos  on Stanwell Road, Matthew Holland and Charlotte Court, have delivered over  meals to frontline facilities in Penarth since the beginning of the pandemic, including the Marie Curie Hospice on Bridgeman Road.Now the pair have plans to extend their operations.They have raised over pound for the charitable cause, which includes money collected in a fundraiser by the community support group, Helping Hands Penarth.ldquoWe closed the shop three weeks ago and used all the leftover stock to do the first delivery to the hospital, explained Matthew.ldquoWersquove all got to be doing something and we felt like we had to utilize the shop and give something back to the guys that are putting their lives at risk.ldquoPenarth is a really small town and yoursquove just got to try and support each other as much as possible.ldquoI think yoursquove got to step up and do as much as you can,you can. Wersquove got the capacity to do it.Matthew went on to describe the atmosphere at Llandough Hospital.ldquoWersquore both in Penarth and wersquove lived here all our lives. Its important to us that we support it as much as possible.ldquoIts uplting being able to do that. It was so emotional being able to see the nurses on the Covid ward.ldquoFor me and Charlotte it was very humbling because those guys are putting their lives at risk and theyrsquore asking for stuff for patients, not for themselves.ldquoWe were quite tearful because we didnrsquot want to leave them there ndash but theyrsquore doing it day in-day out without batting an eyelid. Amazing people.Alongside their charitable work, Matthew and Charlotte have adapted to the challenging economic climate by introducing a delivery service for their customers.The pair have been working without the support of their staff who they had to furlough after the government closed all non-essential shops.ldquoWersquove started doing take-out because we canrsquot afford to do nothing for three months. title: strategy announced lead wales lockdown
story: The framework will help to determine when the strict stay-at-home restrictions can begin to be relaxed in Wales and will help to find a way for people in Wales to live and work alongside coronavirus.A Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing is being developed through the office of the Chief Medical Officer, Dr Frank Atherton. This will highlight the importance of community testing and support the containment of emerging coronavirus infections as and when restrictions are eased.Launching the framework, the First Minister said: ldquoOur approach to date has been one of lockdown. We have taken unprecedented steps to protect everyone, but particularly those most at risk from serious illness.ldquoThis has helped the NHS prepare and cope with coronavirus and, even though we have sadly seen more than  people die, it has helped to save many more lives. But this strategy comes with its own costs to peoplersquos wider health and wellbeing and long-term costs to our economy.ldquoWe are keeping these regulations under constant review. We know coronavirus will be with us for a long time yet but we want to see whether there are things we can do while we continue to tackle the virus and while the search for better treatments and a vaccine continue.The framework ndash and the seven questions ndash will help determine when the time is right to relax some of the stay-at home regulations.The seven questions are:bull Would easing a restriction have a negative effect on containing the virus bull Does a particular measure pose a low risk of further infection bull How can it be monitored and enforced bull Can it be reversed quicklyit creates unintended consequences bull Does it have a positive economic benefit bull Does it have a positive impact on peoplersquos wellbeing bull Does it have a positive impact on equality The Chief Medical Officer for Walesrsquo office has developed the Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing.It will have four main strands ndash improved surveillance of cases of coronavirus effective identication of cases and contact tracing learning from international experience and engaging with the public.Dr Atherton said: ldquoAction to ease the lockdown restrictions will need to be supported by a comprehensive public health response, which will need to developed quickly and at scale.ldquoAcross the UK, we have worked and put in place unprecedented measures to contain and delay the spread of coronavirus. We have also worked to reduce the overall impact of the virus by strengthening essential services, including healthcare.ldquoWe are now working towards a new recovery phase to lead us out of the pandemic but only when the conditions are right.The First Minister added: ldquoCoronavirus is not going to disappear ndash it is likely it will be with us for a long time. We will need to have some sort of restrictions in place for some time yet to continue to control the spread of the virus and reduce community transmission. This framework will help us determine what is right for Wales.ldquoThere is a long road ahead of us towards recovery to pre-pandemic levels, butwe continue to work together, I hope we will be able to make changes to the restrictions and see a gradualto something resembling normal le.The Welsh Government has worked closely with the rest of the UK throughout the pandemic and has shared the development of the framework with the Scottish, Northern Irish and the UK governments. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... services to get our care homes what they need, said Mr Britton.ldquoTheyrsquovebeen really well received.According to Mr Britton, the material for the visors was purchased using funds from the school earlier this week following a review by the Penarth Town Council.The council previously closed the cemetery to visitors in March to tackle the spread of the coronavirus.The cemetery will be be open for visits on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays between am and pm, a council spokesman confirmed.He said: ldquoWe understand peoplersquos wish in the current pandemic to mourn and pay respects to those who remain dear to them.ldquoTo ensure that this can continue, we ask all visitors to take good care of themselves and others by observing current health guidance, including social distancing.ldquoWe must also ask that the grounds are not used for exercise or dog walking.ldquoPlease help us look after the cemetery by taking any waste materials home.ldquoPlease note that the toilets remain closed.ldquoFor health and safety reasons, it will be necessary for us to close the grounds during a funeral.ldquoIn current circumstances grounds maintenance has been scaled back and normal maintenance levels will resume when it is safe to do so.ldquoWe hope that reopening the cemetery brings comfort and thank you for supporting us in keeping yourself and others safe.The change comes after the Welsh Government introduced minor adjustments to the lockdown measures.The new rules allow people to exercise more than once a day near their home and enabled local authorities to begin the process of planning how to safely reopen libraries and municipal recycling centres.Garden centres are also allowed to reopen.Last week there were several incidents at the Merthyr Dyfan Cemetery in Barry which reopened on May .Barry Town Council received reports that visitors had not observed social distancing.On one occasion, a member of the public spat at a security guard whilst another title: battersea boss offers insight dogs cats coping lockdown
story: The south London-based charity, ordinarily home to up to  cats and dogs across its three sites, currently has around  would-be pets cared for by a skeleton staff as social distancing and temporary safety measures introduced following the coronavirus outbreak continue to pose challenges for operations.But despite the changes ndash and a multimillion-pound drop in its revenue stream ndash Battersea Dogs and Cats Home said its long-term residents have been enjoying the extra attention after staff doubled rehoming efforts and sent another  animals out for fostering in the week leading up to lockdown, leaving the number of furry occupants at just a fraction of their normal capacity.Rob Young, head of centre operations, told the PA news agency: ldquoThe animals are quite happy, the ratio of staff per animal is probably higher than it normally would be before the lockdown so all the dogs are getting at least two walks a day along with some socialisation, and all the cats are getting as many cuddles as they wish.ldquoNot all cats like a cuddle as you probably know.ldquoTherersquos no stress, withtrains going past the Battersea centre in London in particular.ldquoThe dogs havenrsquot been walked off site because we didnrsquot want to risk it in that way. Otherwise wersquove got the paddocks, wersquove got the green areas within the three centresas well, so theyrsquove been getting a lot of attention. Theyrsquove been quite happy. vw,vw,px, px"Bounty, an eight-year-old domestic short-hair, who loves being in the sun Mr Young said the charity was ldquoinundated with requests to temporarily foster animals as lockdown restrictions were introduced, and said they were concerned some pets would no longer be wanted as vast numbers of people were urged to work from home.He said: ldquoWe were worried that wersquod see a lot of animals abandoned at our door because of the situation that people find themselves in, but wersquove not seen that either.ldquoI think wersquove been pleasantly surprised with how the public have reacted quite responsibly and the great British public being the animal lovers that they are, I think theyrsquove responded really well. So wersquore really pleased actually how itrsquos gone so far.The charity has now received clearance from Defra to begin rehoming animals, under strict conditions, while preparing to reopen properly when allowed to do so. vw,vw,px, px"Rob Young praised the public for their responsible attitude to taking on pets during lockdown But despite the workaround, the pandemic has caused its revenue stream to be severely affected through a lack of key fundraising events such as marathons.Mr Young said: ldquoWe expect to lose an awful lot of money over the course of this year. We think anything up to about pound million over the next  months.ldquoSo wersquore able to carry on ing as we always would. We have enough reserves to be able to care for our animals and look after our staff. vw,vw,px, px"Judy the six-year-old Belgian shepherd dog is among those waiting for adoption ldquoBut obviously it is a concern that we arenrsquot able to fundraise like we used to do, the same as everybody .For more information on adoption, visit battersea.org.ukGet involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: dunn family calls judge led inquiry accuses government cover up
story: The teenagerrsquos parents urged Dominic Raab to launch the inquiry on Saturday to determine whether there was any misconduct in the way the case was handled.Charlotte Charles and Tim Dunn told the PA news agency they had given the Government a chance to ldquocome clean to us, but claimed they were ldquoslapped in the face each time. vw,vw,px, px"Mr Dunnrsquos family called for a full judge-led public inquiry on Saturday Acting on behalf of the -year-oldrsquos parents, their spokesman Radd Seiger called for the inquiry to investigate who decided suspect Anne Sacoolas could leave the UK and ldquowho ordered that the matter should be covered up.He suggested an inquiry should consider a replacement for the ldquoimbalanced extradition treaty between the UK and the US and to look into why an ambulance took more than  minutes to get to Mr Dunn.PA understands a letter was previously written to Northamptonshire Coroner Anne Pember over the possibility of an inquest being turned into a full public inquiry ndash a request which has been referred to Chief Coroner Mark Lucraft QC.Mr Dunn was killed when his motorbike crashed into a car outside a US military base in the county on August  last year.Sacoolas, , the we of a US intelligence official, claimed diplomatic immunity following the crash and was able toto her home country.She was charged with causing death by dangerous driving in December but an extradition request submitted by the Home Office for the suspect was rejected by US secretary of state Mike Pompeo in January ndash a decision the State Department have since described as ldquofinal.After Mr Seiger called for an inquiry on their behalf, Charlotte Charles and Tim Dunn told PA: ldquoWe canrsquot bring Harry back. We know that.ldquoBut like anyone , we are entitled to see that justice is done for our son, who did nothing wrong.ldquoDespite what the Government think, his le did matter and we are so grateful to Radd for knocking on our door that day when we had been told we had no chance of getting justice.The teenagerrsquos parents continued: ldquoThen with the help of the media, the whole nation and millions of people all around the world, including the wonderful people of America, came to support us too. That has meant the world.ldquoWithout public pressure, this whole disgusting saga would have been buried.We promised Harry we would get him justice.#HarryDunns have today called on the Foreign Secretary @DominicRaab to order a full public inquiry into the handling of events after Harrys death. Please see attached statement. https:t.co oYdAzxPrmdash Radd SeigerMay , ldquoThat is what we will do and no-one will get in our way.ldquoWe have given the Government every chance to come clean to us. They slapped us in the face each time, clearly trying to hide what they did.ldquoOur only wish now, apart from ensuring Mrs Sacoolas faces justice, is that this should never happen to another family again.ldquoFollowing our experience, this Government clearly cannot be trusted to look after us, the people.ldquoAs a nation, we have to get back to a more decent way of doing things.ldquoThis is not the sort of society we should be where our elected officials think itrsquos OK to kick those in most need of help.Calling for the inquiry on behalf of the parents, Mr Seiger told PA: ldquoGiven the horric nature of what has happened in this case, with all its dferent strands and the extent to which Government has sought to cover it up, there must be an inquiry the nation can have confidence in.ldquoAn inquiry can restore trust and faith in Government, so as to ensure that anyone involved in misconduct in public office are held to account and so that lessons are learned and systems are put in place so that no such abuse of human rights is committed by Government again.A spokeswoman for the Foreign Office said: ldquoWe have deep sympathy for Harryrsquos family. title: national museums ni launches new florence nightingale exhibition digitally
story: Mum Victoria making face shields for health workersMan and woman taken to hospital after three vehicle crashNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsNational Museums NI launches new Florence Nightingale exhibition digitallyIn the week that marked the bicentennial anniversary of Florence Nightingale, the pioneer credited as the founder of modern nursing, a new digital exhibition has been launched by National Museums NI and the Florence Nightingale Foundation to highlight the contribution that nursing and midwery has made to le in Northern Ireland.By Julie-Ann SpenceFriday, th May , : am""Florence Nightingale in the Military Hospital at Scutari, . Image © National Army Museum.Florence Nightingale – Nursing and Midwery  Years was originally set to open at the Ulster Museum in March before social distancing measures were introduced.Its launch as a digital exhibition coincides with the th year anniversary of Florence Nightingale’s birthand International Year of the Nurse and Midwe .The special exhibition explores the vital work of nurses and midwives through two centuries of nursing, covering themes such as nursing in wartime, nursing during The Troubles, and nursing education and innovation in Northern Ireland. It also features an original voice recording of Florence Nightingale.Since the lockdown began, National Museums NI has been working to digitise the exhibition and make it accessible to the public.Kathryn Thomson, Chief Executive of National Museums NI, said: “Over the past couple of months our colleagues at National Museums NI have been working hard to find new and innovative ways to make our collections engaging and to reach audiences safely.“During these dficult times it’s important to maintain access to the arts and culture and this latest show represents our first fully digital exhibition. It demonstrates the value of our museums and cultural institutions and the vital role they play in telling the stories that connect our past with our present.“Its timing could not be more appropriate. When social distancing measures were first announced we were keen to ensure this exhibition and celebration of our healthcare workers was made available to the public. title: sean hegarty marathon fundraiser vandalised school
story: Man and woman taken to hospital after three vehicle crashABC Council facing £million lossNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPeopleSean Hegarty in marathon fundraiser for vandalised schoolComedian Sean Hegarty is swapping the stand-up routines for running shoes this weekend in a bid to raise funds for a school hit by a vandalism attack.By The NewsroomFriday, th May , : pmUpdated Friday, th May , : pm""Sean Hegarty : User Sean will be running . milesto raise funds to help with repairs at Tullygally Primary School where thousands of pounds worth of damage was caused when windows were shot out with a pellet gun.For Sean it will be his first marathon in  years - his last was the Belfast marathon - and he assures us he’s looking forward to beating the time he set all those years ago.Of course, he’s not starting from scratch as he’s been running since January and attends Fitzone SRG at St Anthony’s, Craigavon, with his son - giving him a chance to spend more time with the youngster and get fit together.He said: “I’ve been building up the distance over the past few weeks and this gives me an opportunity to push myself and raise funds for a school I run past every day.”He’s aiming to raise £, for the school which was damaged sometime on Wednesday night Thursday morning with a number of windows broken using a pellet gun.Sean is a winner of Ireland’s Funniest Joke  and star of Ireland’s Got Talent. He is known as his alter-ego, comedy character ‘Rodney’, and has racked up over  million video views online. A writer, event host, presenter on Cool FM, podcaster, actor and comedian, Sean and his we actress Diona Doherty Hegarty have now branched into writing and before lockdown had been commissioned to write five stage shows.The couple also had a viral video a few years back - the Derry Londonderry hitchhiker sketch from BBC NI’s ‘Late Licence’ show.Now Sean won’t be hitching any lts tomorrow morning as he undertakes his marathon at the lakes - and he’s hoping to beat his four and a half hour time from  years ago.To support his fundraising effort visit GoFundMe and please give generously!A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. However, over the past few weeks clarityhas been provided by Ministers through a set of guidelines which it is suggested, should be address prior to any formal decision to reopen being made.As such council officers have proposed an initialoperating model to see the borough’s four main sitesreopen.The report states that services at these premises would be availableto the general public on weekdays from am to pm.A Saturday morning slot would,these recommendation are approved by Council, be available only for health care and associated workers.It is also suggested that initiallywaste is limited to black bag and potentially green waste and that only cars are to be permitted.The need to limit the reopening to the four main recycling initially, is, the report claims, “based on a mix of waste product capacity and maximising the use of key staff ”.The report concludes by stating that the implementation of this model is dependant on Council’s abilityto redeploy staff and on the speed at which waste operators could get their service operational, ensuring that the vehicles are road worthy.Given these considerations the report suggests it may take up to five working days from a decision being made to the actual reopening of the four sites.This issue is due to be debated at tonight’s virtual council meeting.The meeting is set to get underway at .pm and members of the public can watch the debate by clicking hereA message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: council agrees reopen its main recycling centres
story: Thieves rob ATM from field behind NI filling stationMan and woman taken to hospital after three vehicle crashNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPoliticsCouncil agrees to reopen its main recycling centresThe four main recycling centres in Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council will open early next week, it has been confirmed.By The NewsroomFriday, th May , : pm""The matter was discussed at Thursday night’s virtual council meeting, just hours after the Executive announced recycling centres and garden centres can reopen from Monday, May .Prior to the meeting the Council’s Strategic Director, Mark Parkinson, had submitted a plan, for member’s consideration, to reopen recycling centres across the borough.The plan sought to reopen the borough’s four main recycling centres inArmagh, Banbridge, Lurgan and Portadown. The borough’s five other sitesare to reopen at an unspecied later date.Addressing this plan, the Director acknowledgedthat the Executive’s announcementhad changed the nature of the debate.“There was an announcement this afternoon [Thursday] from the Executive that said travelling to recycling centres is, from Monday, an appropriate reason for travel,” said Mr Parkinson.“With that in mind, what I would suggest to members is that we progress with the proposed model initially. However in the following days, we work to open the other five sites shortly afterwards.”Addressing the issue SDLP group leader, Councillor Thomas O’Hanlon asked that this matter be dealt with under scheme of delegation in order to ensure that recycling centres can be opened promptly.He also asked that Council’s bulky waste collection service be “restarted in tandem” with the reopening of recycling centres and queriedhow recycling centres could cater for those who are shielding.His comments were address by Council’s ChiefExecutive, Roger Wilson, who said party group leaders had made their “desire to get centres open as quickly as possible” clear.He also said it would be a “matter of practicality”the decision were to remain under delegationas this would “remove the element of having to go through a call in period”.Council’s Strategic Director, Mark Parkinson, said he would agree with Councillor O’Hanlon “on the point about bulky waste collection restarting at the same time” as recycling centres reopen.Ulster Unionist Party councillor, Julie Flaherty, commendedthe “fantastic job” waste men and women are doing across the borough and said her party would support steps to reopen these centres quickly and safely.The Alliance Party’s Cllr Eoin Tennyson asked about PPE for staff and was informed by Mr Parkinson that the council has a sufficient supply of PPE.The Director also informed Cllr Tennyson that Council is meeting with unions “every morning” to make sure “the equipment is reaching the right people” and the supply of this equipment is “reviewed on a regular basis”.Councillor Darryn Causby welcomed the fact Council can now “get these centres open” and asked what type of material would be accepted at that start.He was informed by Mr Parkinson that in line with the initialproposal the sites will accept “black bags and general waste until processors are back up and running” and that “over a period of time, we will expand the waste cycle”.Independent Councillor Paul Berry called for a “common sense approach” to allowing certain trailers access to recycling centres.“Some areas across this borough, do not have a brown bin for their garden waste and I think their needs to be a common sense approach towards letting some trailers with garden waste have access to these sites,” said Cllr Berry.Lord Mayor, Councillor Mealla Campbell, agreed with this point. However, the Council’s Strategic Director explained that restricting sites to cars and black bags only is an attempt to deal with an expected initialpeak in demand.“We will get a vast number of people looking to bring black bags and access the centres,” said Mr Parkinson. “We are limiting it to cars initiallyto manage capacity. Once we are over that peak, and we expect that to be within a few days, we can look at allowing access to trailers and white vans.“In regards to smaller sites, the other thing to consider is their size,we get the demand we expect, we will be forced to close them again very very quickly as they will be at capacity.”DUP group leader, Councillor Mark Baxter said he was concernedthatsmaller sites were not opened quickly, residents in those areas could feel “short changed”.His party colleague Alderman Gareth Wilson, said this issue was one the general public are “engaged with” and are aware that it is a service that can be offeredwith “social distancing kept in place”.He also said Council needs to be very careful about getting the message across about what type of material can be accepted at these centres.This view was agreed with by DUP Alderman Paul Rankin who said thatany announcementwas to be made, Council would need to “give a timeframe or specydetails on when the other five sites are going to open”.SDLP Councillor Thomas Larkham enquired about the openingtimes for the four main centres and was told they would open from Monday – Friday am to pm, initially, in line with the report presented to members.It was also made clear, following a query from SDLP Councillor Eamon McNeil, that a special time slot for NHS and other care staff would be in operation on Saturday mornings from am to  noon.DUP Councillor Margaret Tinsley then asked that Saturday opening hours be extended to allow all those back at work to access to the sites.An announcementon the issue is expected from Council tonight , following a party group leaders’ meeting where the issues raised during the debate will be discussed.Adam Morton , Local Democracy Reporting Service""Most Popular."
